custom_item_1.description: GEN000000-SOL00440 - The root account must be the only account with GID of 0.
custom_item_1.info: Accounts with a GID of 0 have root group privileges.
custom_item_1.solution: Change the default GID of non-root accounts to a valid GID other than 0.
custom_item_1.name: passwd_zero_uid

custom_item_2.description: GEN000300 - All accounts on the system must have unique user or account names.
custom_item_2.info: A unique user name is the first part of the identification and authentication process.  If user names are not unique, there can be no accountability on the system for auditing purposes.  Multiple accounts sharing the same name could result in the Denial of Service to one or both of the accounts or unauthorized access to files or privileges.
custom_item_2.solution: Change user account names, or delete accounts, so each account has a unique name.
custom_item_2.name: passwd_duplicate_username

custom_item_3.description: GEN000320 - All accounts must be assigned unique User Identification Numbers (UIDs).
custom_item_3.info: Accounts sharing a UID have full access to each others' files.  This has the same effect as sharing a login.  There is no way to assure identification, authentication, and accountability because the system sees them as the same user. If the duplicate UID is 0, this gives potential intruders another privileged account to attack.
custom_item_3.solution: Edit user accounts to provide unique UIDs for each account.
custom_item_3.name: passwd_duplicate_uid

custom_item_4.description: GEN000380 - All GIDs referenced in the /etc/passwd file must be defined in the /etc/group file.
custom_item_4.info: If a user is assigned the GID of a group not existing on the system, and a group with the same GID is subsequently created, the user may have unintended rights to the group.
custom_item_4.solution:
Add a group to the system for each GID referenced that does not have a corresponding group.

#/usr/sbin/groupadd < group >
custom_item_4.name: passwd_invalid_gid

custom_item_5.description: GEN000880 - The root account must be the only account having an UID of 0.
custom_item_5.info: If an account has an UID of 0, it has root authority. Multiple accounts with an UID of 0 afford more opportunity for potential intruders to guess a password for a privileged account.
custom_item_5.solution: Remove or change the UID of accounts other than root that have UID 0.
custom_item_5.name: passwd_zero_uid

custom_item_6.description: GEN000940 - The root accounts executable search path must contain only authorized paths.
custom_item_6.info: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, two consecutive colons, or a single period, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Entries starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_6.solution:
Edit the root user's local initialization files. Remove any empty path entries. Remove any relative path entries that have not been documented with the ISSO.

Edit the root user's local initialization files and remove any empty entry that is defined.
custom_item_6.name: dot_in_root_path_variable

custom_item_7.description: GEN000960 - The root account must not have world-writable directories in its executable search path.
custom_item_7.info: If the root search path contains a world-writable directory, malicious software could be placed in the path by intruders and/or malicious users and inadvertently run by root with all of root's privileges.
custom_item_7.solution:
For each world-writable path in root's executable search path, perform one of the following.

1. Remove the world-writable permission on the directory.
Procedure:
# chmod o-w2. Remove the world-writable directory from the executable search path.

Procedure:
Identify and edit the initialization file referencing the world-writable directory and remove it from the PATH variable.
custom_item_7.name: writeable_dirs_in_root_path_variable

custom_item_8.description: GEN001160 - All files and directories must have a valid owner.
custom_item_8.info: Unowned files and directories may be unintentionally inherited if a user is assigned the same UID as the UID of the unowned files.
custom_item_8.solution: All directories and files (executable and data) will have an identifiable owner and group name. Either trace files to an authorized user, change the file's owner to root, or delete them. Determine the legitimate owner of the files and use the chown command to set the owner and group to the correct value. If the legitimate owner cannot be determined, change the owner to root (but make sure none of the changed files remain executable because they could be Trojan horses or other malicious code). Examine the files to determine their origin and the reason for their lack of an owner/group.
custom_item_8.name: find_orphan_files

custom_item_9.description: GEN001170 - All files and directories must have a valid group-owner.
custom_item_9.info: Files without a valid group-owner may be unintentionally inherited if a group is assigned the same GID as the GID of the files without a valid group-owner.
custom_item_9.solution:
Change the group owner for each file without a valid group owner.
# chgrp/tmp/a-file-without-a-valid-group-owner
custom_item_9.name: find_orphan_files

custom_item_10.description: GEN001440 - All interactive users must be assigned a home directory in the /etc/passwd file.
custom_item_10.info: If users do not have a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they own.
custom_item_10.solution: Assign a home directory to any user without one.
custom_item_10.name: accounts_without_home_dir

custom_item_11.description: GEN001460 - All interactive user home directories defined in the /etc/passwd file must exist.
custom_item_11.info: If a user has a home directory defined that does not exist, the user may be given the / directory, by default, as the current working directory upon logon.  This could create a Denial of Service because the user would not be able to perform useful tasks in this location.
custom_item_11.solution:
If a user has no home directory, determine why. If possible, delete accounts that have no home directory. If the account is valid, then create the home directory using the appropriate system administration utility or manually.

For instance: mkdir directoryname; copy the skeleton files into the directory; chown accountname for the new directory and the skeleton files. Document all changes.

Update the sixth field in the /etc/passwd file to reflect the user's home directory.
# usermod -d
OR
# vi /etc/passwd
custom_item_11.name: accounts_without_home_dir

custom_item_12.description: GEN001470 - The /etc/passwd file must not contain password hashes.
custom_item_12.info: If password hashes are readable by non-administrators, the passwords are subject to attack through lookup tables or cryptographic weaknesses in the hashes.
custom_item_12.name: passwd_shadowed

custom_item_13.description: GEN001480 - All users' home directories must have mode 0750 or less permissive.
custom_item_13.info: Excessive permissions on home directories allow unauthorized access to user's files.
custom_item_13.solution:
Change the mode of users' home directories to 0750 or less permissive.

Procedure (example):
# chmod 0750
custom_item_13.name: accounts_bad_home_permissions

custom_item_14.description: GEN001500 - All interactive user's home directories must be owned by their respective users.
custom_item_14.info: If users do not own their home directories, unauthorized users could access user files.
custom_item_14.solution:
Change the owner of a user's home directory to its assigned user.

Procedure:
# chown
custom_item_14.name: accounts_bad_home_permissions

custom_item_15.description: GEN001520 - All interactive user's home directories must be group-owned by the home directory owner's primary group.
custom_item_15.info: If the GID of the home directory is not the same as the GID of the user, this would allow unauthorized access to files.
custom_item_15.solution:
Change the group owner for user's home directories to the primary group of the assigned user.

Procedure:
# chgrp groupname directoryname

(Replace examples with appropriate group and home directory.)

Document all changes.
custom_item_15.name: accounts_bad_home_group_permissions

custom_item_16.description: GEN001860 - All local initialization files must be owned by the user or root.
custom_item_16.info: Local initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login.  Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.
custom_item_16.solution:
Change the ownership of the startup and login files in the user's directory to the user or root, as appropriate.  Examine each user's home directory and verify all file names beginning with '.' are owned by the owner of the directory or root.  If they are not, use the chown command to change the owner to the user and research the reasons why the owners were not assigned as required.

Procedure:
# chown username .filename
Document all changes.
custom_item_16.name: home_dir_localization_files_user_check

custom_item_17.description: GEN001870 - Local initialization files must be group-owned by the user's primary group or root.
custom_item_17.info: Local initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login.  Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.
custom_item_17.solution:
Change the group-owner of the local initialization file to the user's primary group, or root.
# chgrp [USER's primary GID] ~USER/[local initialization file]
custom_item_17.name: home_dir_localization_files_group_check

custom_item_18.description: GEN002140 - All shells referenced in /etc/passwd must be listed in the /etc/shells file, except any shells specified for the purpose of preventing logins.
custom_item_18.info: The shells file lists approved default shells.  It helps provide layered defense to the security approach by ensuring users cannot change their default shell to an unauthorized shell that may not be secure.
custom_item_18.solution: Use the chsh utility or edit the /etc/passwd file and correct the error by changing the default shell of the account in error to an acceptable shell name contained in the /etc/shells file.
custom_item_18.name: invalid_login_shells

custom_item_19.description: GEN002200 - All shell files must be owned by root or bin.
custom_item_19.info: If shell files are owned by users other than root or bin, they could be modified by intruders or malicious users to perform unauthorized actions.
custom_item_19.solution:
Change the ownership of the shell with incorrect ownership.
# chown root
custom_item_19.name: login_shells_bad_owner

custom_item_20.description: GEN002210 - All shell files must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_20.info: If shell files are group-owned by users other than root or a system group, they could be modified by intruders or malicious users to perform unauthorized actions.
custom_item_20.solution:
Change the group-owner of the shell to root, bin, or sys.

Procedure:
# chgrp root
custom_item_20.name: login_shells_bad_owner

custom_item_21.description: GEN002220 - All shell files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
custom_item_21.info: Shells with world/group-write permissions give the ability to maliciously modify the shell to obtain unauthorized access.
custom_item_21.solution:
Change the mode of the shell.
# chmod 0755
custom_item_21.name: login_shells_writeable

custom_item_22.description: GEN002380 - The owner, group owner, mode, ACL, and location of files with the setuid bit set must be documented using site-defined procedures.
custom_item_22.info:
All files with the setuid bit set will allow anyone running these files to be temporarily assigned the UID of the file. While many system files depend on these attributes for proper operation, security problems can result if setuid is assigned to programs that allow reading and writing of files, or shell escapes.  Only default vendor-supplied executables should have the setuid bit set.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_22.solution: Document the files with the setuid bit set or unset the setuid bit on the executable.
custom_item_22.name: find_suid_sgid_files

custom_item_23.description: GEN002440 - The owner, group-owner, mode, ACL, and location of files with the setgid bit set must be documented using site-defined procedures.
custom_item_23.info: All files with the setgid bit set will allow anyone running these files to be temporarily assigned the GID of the file. While many system files depend on these attributes for proper operation, security problems can result if setgid is assigned to programs that allow reading and writing of files, or shell escapes.
custom_item_23.name: find_suid_sgid_files

custom_item_24.description: GEN002480 - Public directories must be the only world-writable directories and world-writable files must be located only in public directories - directories
custom_item_24.info:
World-writable files and directories make it easy for a malicious user to place potentially compromising files on the system.

The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage (e.g., /tmp) and for directories requiring global read/write access.
custom_item_24.solution:
Remove or change the mode for any world-writable file or directory on the system that is not required to be world-writable.

Procedure:
# chmod o-wDocument all changes.
custom_item_24.name: find_world_writeable_directories

custom_item_25.description: GEN002480 - Public directories must be the only world-writable directories and world-writable files must be located only in public directories - files
custom_item_25.info:
World-writable files and directories make it easy for a malicious user to place potentially compromising files on the system.

The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage (e.g., /tmp) and for directories requiring global read/write access.
custom_item_25.solution:
Remove or change the mode for any world-writable file or directory on the system that is not required to be world-writable.

Procedure:
# chmod o-wDocument all changes.
custom_item_25.name: find_world_writeable_files

custom_item_26.description: GEN002500 - The sticky bit must be set on all public directories.
custom_item_26.info:
Failing to set the sticky bit on the public directories allows unauthorized users to delete files in the directory structure.

The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage (e.g., /tmp) and for directories requiring global read/write access.
custom_item_26.solution:
Set the sticky bit on all public directories.

Procedure:
# chmod 1777 /tmp

(Replace /tmp with the public directory missing the sticky bit, if necessary.)
custom_item_26.name: find_world_writeable_directories

custom_item_28.description: GEN000000-SOL00020 - The nosuid option must be configured in the /etc/rmmount.conf file.
custom_item_28.info: The rmmount.conf file controls the mounting of removable media on a Solaris system. Removable media is not to be trusted with privileged access, and therefore the filesystems must be mounted with the nosuid option, which prevents any executables with the setuid bit set on this filesystem from running with owner privileges.
custom_item_28.solution: Edit /etc/rmmount.conf and add the nosuid mount option to the configuration.

custom_item_29.description: GEN000000-SOL00040 - The /etc/security/audit_user file must not define a different auditing level for specific users.
custom_item_29.info:
The audit_user file may be used to selectively audit more, or fewer, auditing features for specific individuals.  If used this way it could subject the activity to a lawsuit and could cause the loss of valuable auditing data in the case of a system compromise.  If an item is audited for one individual (other than for root and administrative users - who have more auditing features) it must be audited for all.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_29.solution: Edit the audit_user file and remove specific user configurations differing from the global audit settings.
custom_item_29.cmd: /usr/bin/egrep -v '^(#|root:)' /etc/security/audit_user 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no additional users" }'

custom_item_30.description: GEN000000-SOL00060 - The /etc/security/audit_user file must be owned by root.
custom_item_30.info: The /etc/security/audit_user is a sensitive file and must be owned by root to prevent possible system compromise.
custom_item_30.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/security/audit_user file to root.
# chown root /etc/security/audit_user

custom_item_31.description: GEN000000-SOL00080 - The /etc/security/audit_user file must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin.
custom_item_31.info: The Solaris audit_user file allows for selective auditing or non-auditing of features for certain users.  If it is not protected, it could be compromised and used to mask audit events.  This could cause the loss of valuable forensics data in the case of a system compromise.
custom_item_31.solution:
Change the group owner of the audit_user file to root, bin, or sys.
Example:
# chgrp root /etc/security/audit_user

custom_item_32.description: GEN000000-SOL00100 - The /etc/security/audit_user file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_32.info: Audit_user is a sensitive file that, if compromised, would allow a malicious user to select auditing parameters to ignore his sessions.  This would allow malicious operations the auditing subsystem would not log for that user.
custom_item_32.solution:
Change the mode of the audit_user file to 0640.
# chmod 0640 /etc/security/audit_user

custom_item_33.description: GEN000000-SOL00110 - The /etc/security/audit_user file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_33.info: Audit_user is a sensitive file that, if compromised, would allow a malicious user to select auditing parameters to ignore their sessions.  This would allow malicious operations the auditing subsystem would not detect for that user.  It could also result in long-term system compromise possibly leading to the compromise of other systems and networks.
custom_item_33.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/security/audit_user
custom_item_33.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/security/audit_user | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_34.description: ASET is run in root crontab

custom_item_35.description: GEN000000-SOL00120 - The ASET master files must be located in the /usr/aset/masters directory - tune.high
custom_item_35.info: If ASET is used and the master files (tune.high, tune.med, tune.low, and uid_aliases) are not located in the proper place, ASET cannot operate correctly and valuable security findings could be lost.
custom_item_35.solution: Install the default ASET configuration files.

custom_item_36.description: GEN000000-SOL00120 - The ASET master files must be located in the /usr/aset/masters directory - tune.med
custom_item_36.info: If ASET is used and the master files (tune.high, tune.med, tune.low, and uid_aliases) are not located in the proper place, ASET cannot operate correctly and valuable security findings could be lost.
custom_item_36.solution: Install the default ASET configuration files.

custom_item_37.description: GEN000000-SOL00120 - The ASET master files must be located in the /usr/aset/masters directory - tune.low
custom_item_37.info: If ASET is used and the master files (tune.high, tune.med, tune.low, and uid_aliases) are not located in the proper place, ASET cannot operate correctly and valuable security findings could be lost.
custom_item_37.solution: Install the default ASET configuration files.

custom_item_38.description: GEN000000-SOL00120 - The ASET master files must be located in the /usr/aset/masters directory - uid_aliases
custom_item_38.info: If ASET is used and the master files (tune.high, tune.med, tune.low, and uid_aliases) are not located in the proper place, ASET cannot operate correctly and valuable security findings could be lost.
custom_item_38.solution: Install the default ASET configuration files.

custom_item_39.description: GEN000000-SOL00160 - If the system is a firewall, ASET must be used on the system, and the firewall parameters must be set in /usr/aset/asetenv.
custom_item_39.info: ASET will not perform firewall tasks if it is not listed as a parameter in /usr/aset/asetenv.
custom_item_39.solution: If the system is used as a firewall and ASET is used, ensure the firewall parameter is configured in /usr/aset/asetenv.

custom_item_40.description: GEN000000-SOL00180 - The Solaris system Automated Security Enhancement Tool (ASET) configurable parameters in the asetenv file must be correct - ASET configurable parameters in the asetenv file must be correct.
custom_item_40.info: If settings in the asetenv file have been modified, then system vulnerabilities may not be detected.
custom_item_40.solution: Restore the ASET configuration to vendor default and only modify the portions of the configuration designated as customizable.
custom_item_40.cmd: /usr/sbin/pkgchk SUNWast 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no issues found" }'

custom_item_42.description: GEN000000-SOL00200 - The asetenv file YPCHECK variable must be set to true when NIS+ is configured.
custom_item_42.info: If YPCHECK is not set to true in asetenv, then ypfiles may not be checked.
custom_item_42.solution: Edit the ASET configuration and set YPCHECK to true on systems running NIS. (If NIS+ is configured, YPCHECK must only be set to false to avoid going into NIS compatibility mode.) Configure NIS to use YPCHECK.

custom_item_43.description: GEN000000-SOL00220 - The /usr/aset/userlist file must exist - exec with userlist
custom_item_43.info: If the userlist file does not exist, then an unauthorized user may exist in the /etc/passwd file.
custom_item_43.solution: Create the /usr/aset/userlist file and populate it with a list of authorized users.

custom_item_44.info: If the userlist file does not exist, then an unauthorized user may exist in the /etc/passwd file.
custom_item_44.solution: Create the /usr/aset/userlist file and populate it with a list of authorized users.

custom_item_45.description: GEN000000-SOL00240 - The /usr/aset/userlist file must be owned by root.
custom_item_45.info: If the userlist file is not owned by root, then an unauthorized user can modify the file and enter an unauthorized user.
custom_item_45.solution:
Use the chmod command to change the owner of the /usr/aset/userlist file.

# chown root /usr/aset/userlist

custom_item_46.description: GEN000000-SOL00250 - The /usr/aset/userlist file must be group-owned by root.
custom_item_46.info: The /usr/aset/userlist file is critical to system security and must be protected from unauthorized access.
custom_item_46.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file.
# chgrp root /usr/aset/userlist

custom_item_47.description: GEN000000-SOL00260 - The /usr/aset/userlist file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_47.info: A permission mask not set to the required level could allow unauthorized access to sensitive system files and resources.
custom_item_47.solution:
Change the mode of the /usr/aset/userlist file to 0600.
# chmod 0600 /usr/aset/userlist

custom_item_48.description: GEN000000-SOL00270 - The /usr/aset/userlist file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_48.info: File system ACLs can provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.
custom_item_48.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /usr/aset/userlist
custom_item_48.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /usr/aset/userlist | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_49.info: If uid_aliases has entries, users may not be properly identified in ASET records.
custom_item_49.solution: Empty or comment out the entries in the uid_aliases file.

custom_item_50.description: GEN000000-SOL00400 - The NFS server must have logging implemented.
custom_item_50.info: Filesystem logging, especially for NFS exported file systems, can be critical to detecting data misuse and possible hardware/system errors that may, otherwise, go unnoticed.
custom_item_50.solution:
Edit /etc/dfs/dfstab and add the log option to all exported filesystems. Run the shareall command for the changes to take effect.

NFS version 2 or 3 must be forced by updating the NFS_SERVER_VERSMAX variable appropriately in /etc/default/nfs and restarting the NFS daemon.
custom_item_50.cmd: /usr/sbin/share | /usr/bin/grep -v 'log=' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "all active shares have logging enabled" }'

custom_item_51.description: GEN000000-SOL00400 - The NFS server must have logging implemented - NFS_SERVER_VERSMAX
custom_item_51.info: Filesystem logging, especially for NFS exported file systems, can be critical to detecting data misuse and possible hardware/system errors that may, otherwise, go unnoticed.
custom_item_51.solution:
Edit /etc/dfs/dfstab and add the log option to all exported filesystems. Run the shareall command for the changes to take effect.

NFS version 2 or 3 must be forced by updating the NFS_SERVER_VERSMAX variable appropriately in /etc/default/nfs and restarting the NFS daemon.

custom_item_52.description: GEN000000-SOL00420 - Hidden extended file attributes must not exist on the system.
custom_item_52.info: Solaris extended attributes are essentially files themselves that are of an arbitrary size and content.  They could be used to hide files from ordinary system file scans.
custom_item_52.solution:
Remove the hidden extended file attributes.
# runatrm
custom_item_52.cmd: /usr/bin/find / -xattr -print -exec runat {} ls -al \\; 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no hidden attributes found" }'

custom_item_53.description: GEN000000-SOL00540 - The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be owned by root - /etc/zones
custom_item_53.info: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.
custom_item_53.solution:
Change the ownership of the files and directories.
# chown -R root /etc/zones

custom_item_54.description: GEN000000-SOL00540 - The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be owned by root - /etc/zones/*
custom_item_54.info: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.
custom_item_54.solution:
Change the ownership of the files and directories.
# chown -R root /etc/zones

custom_item_55.description: GEN000000-SOL00560 - The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin - /etc/zones
custom_item_55.info: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.
custom_item_55.solution:
Change the group ownership of the files and directories.
# chgrp -R sys /etc/zones
# chgrp root /etc/zones/*.xml
# chgrp bin /etc/zones/SUN*.xml

custom_item_56.description: GEN000000-SOL00560 - The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin - /etc/zones/*
custom_item_56.info: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.
custom_item_56.solution:
Change the group ownership of the files and directories.
# chgrp -R sys /etc/zones
# chgrp root /etc/zones/*.xml
# chgrp bin /etc/zones/SUN*.xml

custom_item_57.description: GEN000000-SOL00580 - The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must not be group- or world-writable - /etc/zones
custom_item_57.info: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.
custom_item_57.solution:
Change the mode of the file or directory.

# chmod 0644For directories:
# chmod 0755

custom_item_58.description: GEN000000-SOL00580 - The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must not be group- or world-writable - /etc/zones/*
custom_item_58.info: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.
custom_item_58.solution:
Change the mode of the file or directory.

# chmod 0644For directories:
# chmod 0755

custom_item_59.description: GEN000000-SOL00600 - The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_59.info: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.
custom_item_59.solution:
Remove  the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A-
custom_item_59.cmd: /usr/bin/find /etc/zones -exec /usr/bin/ls -lLd {} \\; | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_60.description: GEN000000-SOL00620 - The inherit-pkg-dir zone option must be set to none or the system default list defined for sparse root zones.
custom_item_60.info: Solaris zones have the capability to inherit elements of the global zone's filesystem, which reduces the amount storage required for a zone, but also limits the flexibility of the zone.  The inherit-pkg-dir option defines which paths are shared between the zones.  If set incorrectly, private information from the global zone could be made available to the non-global zone.  This option must be set to none (for a whole-root non-global zone), the vendor-specified list of paths for sparse-root non-global zones, or a list specified by the SA for operational reasons which has been justified and documented with the IAO.
custom_item_60.solution:
Remove the inherit-pkg-dir lines or the directories not defined for sparse root zones.
# zonecfg -zremove inherit-pkg-dir=
custom_item_60.cmd: /usr/sbin/zoneadm list -i | /usr/bin/egrep -v '^global$' | /usr/bin/xargs -IZONE /usr/sbin/zonecfg -z ZONE info inherit-pkg-dir | /usr/bin/egrep -v '(inherit-pkg-dir|/lib|/usr|/platform|/sbin)' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no additional inherit-pkg-dir found" }'

custom_item_61.description: GEN000000-SOL00640 - The limitpriv zone option must be set to the vendor default or less permissive.
custom_item_61.info: Solaris zones can be assigned privileges generally reserved for the global zone using the limitpriv zone option.  Any privilege assignments in excess of the vendor defaults may provide the ability for a non-global zone to compromise the global zone.
custom_item_61.solution:
Change the limitpriv setting to default.
# zonecfg -zset limitpriv=default
custom_item_61.cmd: /usr/sbin/zoneadm list -i | /usr/bin/egrep -v '^global$' | /usr/bin/xargs -IZONE /usr/sbin/zonecfg -z ZONE info limitpriv | /usr/bin/egrep -v '^limitpriv:( default)? *$' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no additional limitpriv found" }'

custom_item_62.description: GEN000000-SOL00660 - The physical devices must not be assigned to non-global zones.
custom_item_62.info: Solaris non-global zones can be assigned physical hardware devices.  This increases the risk of such a non-global zone having the capability to compromise the global zone.
custom_item_62.solution:
Remove all device assignments from the non-global zone.
# zonecfg -zremove device
custom_item_62.cmd: /usr/sbin/zoneadm list -i | /usr/bin/egrep -v '^global$' | /usr/bin/xargs -IZONE /usr/sbin/zonecfg -z ZONE info device 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no additional device found" }'

custom_item_63.description: GEN000020 - The system must require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes.
custom_item_63.info: If the system does not require valid root authentication before it boots into single-user or maintenance mode, anyone who invokes single-user or maintenance mode is granted privileged access to all files on the system.
custom_item_63.solution:
Edit /etc/default/sulogin and set PASSREQ=YES or remove /etc/default/sulogin entirely.

NOTE: This is a default on Solaris 5.5.1 and later.

custom_item_64.description: GEN000100 - The operating system must be a supported release.
custom_item_64.info:
An operating system release is considered supported if the vendor continues to provide security patches for the product. With an unsupported release, it will not be possible to resolve security issues discovered in the system software.

NOTE: This STIG has been sunset by DISA and vendor support has ended.
custom_item_64.solution: Upgrade to a supported version of the operating system.

custom_item_65.description: GEN000120 - System security patches and updates must be installed and up-to-date.
custom_item_65.info:
Timely patching is critical for maintaining the operational availability, confidentiality, and integrity of Information Technology (IT) systems. However, failure to keep operating system and application software patched is a common mistake made by IT professionals. New patches are released daily, and it is often difficult for even experienced system administrators to keep abreast of all the new patches. When new weaknesses in an operating system exist, patches are usually made available by the vendor to resolve the problems. If the most recent security patches and updates are not installed, unauthorized users may take advantage of weaknesses present in the unpatched software. The lack of prompt attention to patching could result in a system compromise.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_65.solution:
Apply available security updates from Oracle.
# smpatch update

custom_item_66.description: GEN000220 - A file integrity tool must be used at least weekly to check for unauthorized file changes, particularly the addition of unauthorized system libraries or binaries, or for unauthorized modification to authorized system libraries or binaries.
custom_item_66.info:
Changes in system libraries and binaries can indicate compromise or significant system events, such as patching needing to be checked by automated processes and the results reviewed by the SA.

NOTE: The frequency may be increased to daily, if necessary, in accordance with the contingency plan.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_66.solution:
Create a cron job, scheduled to run weekly or more frequently, to run the file integrity tool to check for unauthorized system libraries or binaries, or unauthorized modification to authorized system libraries or binaries.

NOTE: The frequency may be increased to daily, if necessary, in accordance with the contingency plan.

custom_item_67.description: GEN000250 - The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be owned by root.
custom_item_67.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised.  If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not owned by a system account, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.
custom_item_67.solution:
Change the owner of the NTP configuration file to root.
# chown root /etc/inet/ntp.conf

custom_item_68.description: GEN000251 - The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_68.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised.  If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not owned by a system group, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.
custom_item_68.solution:
Change the group owner of the NTP configuration file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/inet/ntp.conf

custom_item_69.description: GEN000252 - The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_69.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised.  If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not protected, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.
custom_item_69.solution:
Change the mode of the NTP configuration file to 0640 or less permissive.
# chmod 0640 /etc/inet/ntp.conf

custom_item_70.description: GEN000253 - The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_70.info: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised.  If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not protected, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.
custom_item_70.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/inet/ntp.conf
custom_item_70.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/inet/ntp.conf  | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_71.description: GEN000290 - The system must not have unnecessary accounts.
custom_item_71.info: Accounts providing no operational purpose provide additional opportunities for system compromise.  Unnecessary accounts include user accounts for individuals not requiring access to the system and application accounts for applications not installed on the system.
custom_item_71.solution: Remove all unnecessary accounts, such as games, from the /etc/passwd file before connecting a system to the network. Other accounts, such as news and gopher, associated with a service not in use should also be removed.

custom_item_72.description: GEN000340 - UIDs reserved for system accounts must not be assigned to non-system accounts.
custom_item_72.info:
Reserved UIDs are typically used by system software packages. If non-system accounts have UIDs in this range, they may conflict with system software, possibly leading to the user having permissions to modify system files.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_72.solution: Change the UID numbers for non-system accounts with reserved UIDs (those less or equal to 99).
custom_item_72.cmd: /usr/bin/awk -F: '{ if ( $3 <= 99  ) print $1": "$5 }' /etc/passwd 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no accounts found" }'

custom_item_73.description: GEN000360 - GIDs reserved for system accounts must not be assigned to non-system groups.
custom_item_73.info:
Reserved GIDs are typically used by system software packages.  If non-system groups have GIDs in this range, they may conflict with system software, possibly leading to the group having permissions to modify system files.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_73.solution:
Change the primary group GID numbers for non-system accounts with reserved primary group GIDs (those less or equal to 99).

# usermod -g
custom_item_73.cmd: /usr/bin/awk -F: '{ if ( $4 <= 99  ) print $1": "$5 }' /etc/passwd 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no accounts found" }'

custom_item_74.description: GEN000400 - The Department of Defense (DoD) login banner must be displayed immediately prior to, or as part of, console login prompts.
custom_item_74.info: Failure to display the login banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.
custom_item_74.solution:
Edit /etc/issue and add one of the DoD login banners (based on the character limitations imposed by the system).

DoD Login Banners:

'You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.'

OR

'I've read & consent to terms in IS user agreem't.'

custom_item_75.description: GEN000402 - The Department of Defense (DoD) login banner must be displayed immediately prior to, or as part of, graphical desktop environment login prompts.
custom_item_75.info:
Failure to display the login banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.

This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices as well as to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems, including thin clients.
custom_item_75.solution:
Create/update /etc/dt/config/C/Xresources with Dtlogin*greeting.labelString: [DoD login banner text].

DoD Login Banners:

'You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.'

OR

'I've read & consent to terms in IS user agreem't.'
custom_item_75.expect: ^[\\s]*Dtlogin\\*greeting\\.labelString:[\\s]+(You are accessing a U.S. Government \\(USG\\) Information System \\(IS\\) that is provided for USG-authorized use only[\\.]|I've read & consent to terms in IS user agreem't[\\.])

custom_item_76.description: GEN000410 - The FTPS/FTP service on the system must be configured with the Department of Defense (DoD) login banner - banner configured
custom_item_76.info:
Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.

NOTE: SFTP and FTPS are encrypted alternatives to FTP that should be used in place of FTP. SFTP is implemented by the SSH service and uses its banner configuration.
custom_item_76.solution:
Edit /etc/ftpd/ftpaccess and add or edit the BANNER parameter ('banner /etc/ftpd/banner.msg').
# vi /etc/ftpd/ftpaccess

Add one of the DoD Login Banners (based on the character limitations imposed by the system) to the /etc/ftpd/banner.msg file.
# vi /et

custom_item_77.description: GEN000410 - The FTPS/FTP service on the system must be configured with the Department of Defense (DoD) login banner - banner content
custom_item_77.info:
Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.

NOTE: SFTP and FTPS are encrypted alternatives to FTP that should be used in place of FTP. SFTP is implemented by the SSH service and uses its banner configuration.
custom_item_77.solution:
Edit /etc/ftpd/ftpaccess and add or edit the BANNER parameter ('banner /etc/ftpd/banner.msg').
# vi /etc/ftpd/ftpaccess

Add one of the DoD Login Banners (based on the character limitations imposed by the system) to the /etc/ftpd/banner.msg file.
# vi /et
custom_item_77.regex: ^[\\s]*I've read & consent to terms in IS user agreem't.[\\s]*$

custom_item_78.description: GEN000440 - Successful and unsuccessful logins and logouts must be logged.
custom_item_78.info: Monitoring and recording successful and unsuccessful logins assist in tracking unauthorized access to the system.  Without this logging, the ability to track unauthorized activity to specific user accounts may be diminished.
custom_item_78.solution:
Verify that login logs are handled correctly in the /etc/syslog.conf file.   Edit the /etc/syslog.conf file and add one of the entries below.

auth.debug    /var/log/authlog
OR
auth.*    /var/log/authlog

Verify that service startup scripts for syslog and utmp (if present) are enabled.

custom_item_79.description: GEN000452 - The system must display the date and time of the last successful account login upon login.
custom_item_79.info: Providing users with feedback on when account accesses last occurred facilitates user recognition and reporting of unauthorized account use.
custom_item_79.solution:
Configure the system to display the date and time of the last successful login upon logging in.

Enable PrintLastLog in the SSH daemon.

To enable PrintLastLog in the SSH daemon, remove any lines disabling this option from /etc/ssh/sshd_config.

custom_item_80.description: GEN000460 - The system must disable accounts after three consecutive unsuccessful login attempts - RETRIES
custom_item_80.info: Disabling accounts after a limited number of unsuccessful login attempts improves protection against password guessing attacks.
custom_item_80.solution:
Set RETRIES to 3 in the /etc/default/login file.
#vi /etc/default/login

Set LOCK_AFTER_RETRIES to YES in the /etc/security/policy.conf file.
#vi /etc/security/policy.conf

custom_item_81.description: GEN000460 - The system must disable accounts after three consecutive unsuccessful login attempts - LOCK_AFTER_RETRIES
custom_item_81.info: Disabling accounts after a limited number of unsuccessful login attempts improves protection against password guessing attacks.
custom_item_81.solution:
Set RETRIES to 3 in the /etc/default/login file.
#vi /etc/default/login

Set LOCK_AFTER_RETRIES to YES in the /etc/security/policy.conf file.
#vi /etc/security/policy.conf

custom_item_82.description: GEN000480 - The delay between login prompts following a failed login attempt must be at least 4 seconds.
custom_item_82.info: Enforcing a delay between successive failed login attempts increases protection against automated password guessing attacks.
custom_item_82.solution: Edit the /etc/default/login file and set SLEEPTIME to 4.

custom_item_83.description: GEN000500 - Graphical desktop environments provided by the system must automatically lock after 15 minutes of inactivity and the system must require users to re-authenticate to unlock the environment - *timeout
custom_item_83.info: If graphical desktop sessions do not lock the session after 15 minutes of inactivity, requiring re-authentication to resume operations, the system or individual data could be compromised by an alert intruder who could exploit the oversight. This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices as well as to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems, including thin clients.
custom_item_83.solution:
Configure the CDE lock manager to lock your screen after a certain amount of inactive time. To configure the CDE lock manager to lock the screen after 15 minutes of inactive time, enter the following commands (be sure NOT to overwrite an existing file).
#
cp /usr/dt/config/C/sys.resources /etc/dt/config/C/sys.resources
# vi /etc/dt/config/C/sys.resources

Locate and add/uncomment/change the line to N=15.
dtsession*lockTimeout:dtsession*lockTimeout: 15

Log out of CDE and log back in to verify that the timeout is in effect.

The timeout parameter in /usr/openwin/lib/app-defaults/XScreenSaver and all users' .xscreensaver files should also be confirmed to be uncommented and set to 0:15:00.

custom_item_84.description: GEN000500 - Graphical desktop environments provided by the system must automatically lock after 15 minutes of inactivity and the system must require users to re-authenticate to unlock the environment - *lock
custom_item_84.info: If graphical desktop sessions do not lock the session after 15 minutes of inactivity, requiring re-authentication to resume operations, the system or individual data could be compromised by an alert intruder who could exploit the oversight. This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices as well as to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems, including thin clients.

custom_item_88.description: GEN000510 - The system must display a publicly-viewable pattern during a graphical desktop environment session lock - saverTimeout
custom_item_88.info:
To protect the on-screen content of a session, it must be replaced with a publicly-viewable pattern upon session lock. Examples of publicly viewable patterns include screen saver patterns, photographic images, solid colors, or a blank screen, so long as none of those patterns convey sensitive information.

This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices, as well as, to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems using remote access protocols.
custom_item_88.solution:
Edit the /etc/dt/config/C/sys.resources file and add/edit the following lines, using 15 for the saverTimeout, and using StartDtscreenBlank for the saverList.

dtsession*saverTimeout:  15
dtsession*saverList: StartDtscreenBlank

custom_item_89.description: GEN000510 - The system must display a publicly-viewable pattern during a graphical desktop environment session lock - saverList
custom_item_89.info:
To protect the on-screen content of a session, it must be replaced with a publicly-viewable pattern upon session lock. Examples of publicly viewable patterns include screen saver patterns, photographic images, solid colors, or a blank screen, so long as none of those patterns convey sensitive information.

This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices, as well as, to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems using remote access protocols.
custom_item_89.solution:
Edit the /etc/dt/config/C/sys.resources file and add/edit the following lines, using 15 for the saverTimeout, and using StartDtscreenBlank for the saverList.

dtsession*saverTimeout:  15
dtsession*saverList: StartDtscreenBlank

custom_item_90.description: GEN000520 - The root user must not own the logon session for an application requiring a continuous display.
custom_item_90.info:
If an application is providing a continuous display and is running with root privileges, unauthorized users could interrupt the process and gain root access to the system.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_90.solution: Configure the system so the owner of a session requiring a continuous screen display, such as a network management display, is not root. Ensure the display is also located in a secure, controlled access area. Document and justify this requirement.  Ensure the terminal and keyboard for the display (or workstation) are secure from all but authorized personnel by maintaining them in a secure area, in a locked cabinet where a swipe card, or other positive forms of identification, must be used to gain entry.

custom_item_91.description: GEN000540 - Users must not be able to change passwords more than once every 24 hours - /etc/shadow
custom_item_91.info:
The ability to change passwords frequently facilitates users reusing the same password. This can result in users effectively never changing their passwords. This would be accomplished by users changing their passwords when required and then immediately changing it to the original value.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_91.solution:
Edit the /etc/default/passwd file and set the variable 'MINWEEKS' to 1 or greater.
Set the per-user minimum password change times by using the following command on each user account.
# passwd -n
custom_item_91.cmd: (/usr/bin/logins -uo; /usr/bin/cat /etc/shadow) | /usr/bin/awk -F: '$4 < 1 || int($2) > 99 { print $1 }' | /usr/bin/sort | /usr/bin/uniq -d 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no accounts found" }'

custom_item_92.description: GEN000540 - Users must not be able to change passwords more than once every 24 hours - MINWEEKS
custom_item_92.info: The ability to change passwords frequently facilitates users reusing the same password. This can result in users effectively never changing their passwords. This would be accomplished by users changing their passwords when required and then immediately changing it to the original value.
custom_item_92.solution:
Edit the /etc/default/passwd file and set the variable 'MINWEEKS' to 1 or greater.
Set the per-user minimum password change times by using the following command on each user account.
# passwd -n

custom_item_93.description: GEN000560 - The system must not have accounts configured with blank or null passwords.
custom_item_93.info: If an account is configured for password authentication but does not have an assigned password, it may be possible to log into the account without authentication.  If the root user is configured without a password, the entire system may be compromised.  For user accounts not using password authentication, the account must be configured with a password lock value instead of a blank or null value.
custom_item_93.solution: Remove, lock, or configure a password for any account with a blank password.
custom_item_93.cmd: /usr/bin/logins -p 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no accounts found" }'

custom_item_94.description: GEN000580 - The system must require passwords contain a minimum of 15 characters.
custom_item_94.info: The use of longer passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques by increasing the password search space.
custom_item_94.solution: Edit /etc/default/passwd and set the PASSLENGTH variable to 15 or greater.

custom_item_95.description: GEN000585 - The system must enforce compliance of the entire password during authentication - /etc/shadow
custom_item_95.info: Some common password hashing schemes only process the first eight characters of a user's password, which reduces the effective strength of the password.
custom_item_95.solution:
Edit /etc/security/policy.conf and add or change the CRYPT_DEFAULT setting to something other than __unix__, such as 6.  Allowable values for CRYPT_DEFAULT may be found in the /etc/security/crypt.conf file.

Change any passwords using non-compliant hashes.

custom_item_96.description: GEN000585 - The system must enforce compliance of the entire password during authentication - /etc/passwd
custom_item_96.info: Some common password hashing schemes only process the first eight characters of a user's password, which reduces the effective strength of the password.
custom_item_96.solution:
Edit /etc/security/policy.conf and add or change the CRYPT_DEFAULT setting to something other than __unix__, such as 6.  Allowable values for CRYPT_DEFAULT may be found in the /etc/security/crypt.conf file.

Change any passwords using non-compliant hashes.

custom_item_97.description: GEN000590 - The system must use a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm for generating account password hashes - CRYPT_DEFAULT
custom_item_97.info: Systems must employ cryptographic hashes for passwords using the SHA-2 family of algorithms or FIPS 140-2 approved successors. The use of unapproved algorithms may result in weak password hashes more vulnerable to compromise.
custom_item_97.solution:
Edit the /etc/security/policy.conf file.
# vi /etc/security/policy.conf
Uncomment or add the CRYPT_ALGORITHMS_ALLOW line and set it to '5,6'. Update the CRYPT_DEFAULT default line to be equal to 5 or 6. The following lines are acceptable.

CRYPT_ALGORITHMS_ALLOW=5,6
CRYPT_DEFAULT=6

custom_item_98.description: GEN000590 - The system must use a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm for generating account password hashes - CRYPT_ALGORITHMS_ALLOW
custom_item_98.info: Systems must employ cryptographic hashes for passwords using the SHA-2 family of algorithms or FIPS 140-2 approved successors. The use of unapproved algorithms may result in weak password hashes more vulnerable to compromise.

Uncomment or add the CRYPT_ALGORITHMS_ALLOW line and set it to '5,6'. Update the CRYPT_DEFAULT default line to be equal to 5 or 6. The following lines are acceptable.

CRYPT_DEFAULT=6

custom_item_99.description: GEN000595 - The password hashes stored on the system must have been generated using a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm - /etc/shadow
custom_item_99.info: Systems must employ cryptographic hashes for passwords using the SHA-2 family of algorithms or FIPS 140-2 approved successors. The use of unapproved algorithms may result in weak password hashes more vulnerable to compromise.
custom_item_99.solution:
If the /etc/security/crypt.conf file does not support FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithms, upgrade to at least the Solaris 10 8/07 release.

Edit the /etc/security/policy.conf file.
# vi /etc/security/policy.conf
Uncomment or add the CRYPT_ALGORITHMS_ALLOW line and set it to '5,6'. Update the CRYPT_DEFAULT default line to be equal to 5 or 6. The following lines are acceptable.

CRYPT_ALGORITHMS_ALLOW=5,6
CRYPT_DEFAULT=6

Update passwords for all accounts with non-compliant password hashes.

custom_item_103.description: GEN000600 - The system must require passwords to contain at least one uppercase alphabetic character.
custom_item_103.info: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated.  The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques.  Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.
custom_item_103.solution: Edit /etc/default/passwd and set the MINUPPER setting to at least 1.

custom_item_104.description: GEN000620 - The system must require passwords to contain at least one numeric character.
custom_item_104.info: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated.  The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques.  Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.
custom_item_104.solution: Edit /etc/default/passwd and set the MINDIGIT setting to 1.

custom_item_105.description: GEN000640 - The system must require passwords to contain at least one special character.
custom_item_105.info: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated.  The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques.  Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.

custom_item_106.description: GEN000680 - The system must require passwords to contain no more than three consecutive repeating characters.
custom_item_106.info: To enforce the use of complex passwords, the number of consecutive repeating characters is limited.  Passwords with excessive repeated characters may be more vulnerable to password-guessing attacks.

custom_item_107.description: GEN000700 - User passwords must be changed at least every 60 days - configured
custom_item_107.info: Limiting the lifespan of authenticators limits the period of time an unauthorized user has access to the system while using compromised credentials and reduces the period of time available for password-guessing attacks to run against a single password.
custom_item_107.solution:
Set the max days field to 60 for all user accounts.
# passwd -x 60Set the MAXWEEKS parameter in /etc/default/passwd to a positive, non-zero value of 8 or less.

custom_item_108.description: GEN000700 - User passwords must be changed at least every 60 days - account report
custom_item_108.info: Limiting the lifespan of authenticators limits the period of time an unauthorized user has access to the system while using compromised credentials and reduces the period of time available for password-guessing attacks to run against a single password.
custom_item_108.solution:
Set the max days field to 60 for all user accounts.
# passwd -x 60Set the MAXWEEKS parameter in /etc/default/passwd to a positive, non-zero value of 8 or less.
custom_item_108.cmd: /usr/bin/awk -F: '($5 == 0 || $5 > 60) && $2 !~ /^(\\*LK\\*|NP)$/ { print $1":"$5; n++ } END { if (!n) print "no accounts found" }' /etc/shadow

custom_item_109.description: GEN000750 - The system must require at least eight characters be changed between the old and new passwords during a password change.
custom_item_109.info: To ensure password changes are effective in their goals, the system must ensure old and new passwords have significant differences.  Without significant changes, new passwords may be easily guessed based on the value of a previously compromised password.
custom_item_109.solution: Edit /etc/default/passwd and set or add a MINDIFF setting equal to or greater than 8.

custom_item_110.description: GEN000760 - Accounts must be locked upon 35 days of inactivity.
custom_item_110.info:
On some systems, accounts with disabled passwords still allow access using rcp, remsh, or rlogin through equivalent remote hosts. All that is required is the remote host name and the user name match an entry in a hosts.equiv file and have a .rhosts file in the user directory. Using a shell called /bin/false or /dev/null (or an equivalent) will add a layered defense.

Non-interactive accounts on the system, such as application accounts, may be documented exceptions.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_110.solution:
All inactive accounts will have /bin/false, /usr/bin/false, or /dev/null as the default shell in the /etc/passwd file and have the password disabled. Disable the inactive accounts. Examine the inactive accounts using the last command. Note the date of last login for each account. If any (other than system and application accounts) exceed 35 days, then disable them by placing a shell of /bin/false or /dev/null in the shell field of the passwd file entry for that account. An alternative, and preferable method, is to disable the account using smc or the passwd command.

# passwd -l < account to lock >
custom_item_110.cmd: /usr/bin/logins -uo | /usr/bin/cut -f1 -d: | /usr/bin/xargs -n1 -iUSER /usr/bin/last -n 1 -a USER | /usr/bin/awk 'NF > 6 { print; n++ } END { if (!n) print "no accounts logged in" }'

custom_item_111.description: GEN000790 - The system must prevent the use of dictionary words for passwords - DICTIONDBDIR
custom_item_111.info: An easily guessable password provides an open door to any external or internal malicious intruder.  Many computer compromises occur as the result of account name and password guessing.  This is generally done by someone with an automated script using repeated logon attempts until the correct account and password pair is guessed.  Utilities, such as cracklib, can be used to validate passwords are not dictionary words and meet other criteria during password changes.
custom_item_111.solution: Edit /etc/default/passwd; add or set DICTIONLIST to the dictionary file and DICTIONDBDIR to a database directory such as /var/passwd.  Generate the password dictionary by running the mkpwdict command.

custom_item_115.description: GEN000800 - The system must prohibit the reuse of passwords within five iterations.
custom_item_115.info: If a user, or root, used the same password continuously or was allowed to change it back shortly after being forced to change it to something else, it would provide a potential intruder with the opportunity to keep guessing at one user's password until it was guessed correctly.

custom_item_116.description: GEN000850 - The system must restrict the ability to switch to the root user to members of a defined group - type=role
custom_item_116.info: Configuring a supplemental group for users permitted to switch to the root user prevents unauthorized users from accessing the root account, even with knowledge of the root credentials.
custom_item_116.solution:
Convert the root user into a role.
# usermod -K type=role root

Add the root role to authorized users' logins.
# usermod -R root

custom_item_117.description: GEN000850 - The system must restrict the ability to switch to the root user to members of a defined group - roles=root
custom_item_117.info: Configuring a supplemental group for users permitted to switch to the root user prevents unauthorized users from accessing the root account, even with knowledge of the root credentials.
custom_item_117.solution:
Convert the root user into a role.
# usermod -K type=role root

Add the root role to authorized users' logins.
# usermod -R root

custom_item_118.description: GEN000900 - The root user's home directory must not be the root directory (/).
custom_item_118.info: Changing the root home directory to something other than / and assigning it a 0700 protection makes it more difficult for intruders to manipulate the system by reading the files that root places in its default directory. It also gives root the same discretionary access control for root's home directory as for the other plain user home directories.
custom_item_118.solution:
The root home directory should be something other than / (such as /rootdir).

Procedure:
# mkdir /rootdir
# chown root /rootdir
# chgrp root /rootdir
# chmod 700 /rootdir
# cp -r /.??* /rootdir

Edit the passwd file and change the root home directory to /rootdir. The cp -r /.??* command copies all files and subdirectories of file names beginning with '.' into the new root directory, which preserves the previous root environment. The cp command must be executed from the / directory.

custom_item_119.description: GEN000920 - The root account's home directory (other than /) must have mode 0700.
custom_item_119.info: Permissions greater than 0700 could allow unauthorized users access to the root home directory.
custom_item_119.solution:
The root home directory will have permissions of 0700. Do not change the protections of the / directory. Use the following command to change protections for the root home directory.
# chmod 0700 /rootdir.

custom_item_120.description: GEN000930 - The root account's home directory must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_120.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.
custom_item_120.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the directory.
# chmod A- ~root
custom_item_120.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd @ROOT_HOME@ | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_121.description: GEN000980 - The system must prevent the root account from directly logging in except from the system console.
custom_item_121.info: Limiting the root account direct logins to only system consoles protects the root account from direct unauthorized access from a non-console device.
custom_item_121.solution: Edit the /etc/default/login file and uncomment the line containing /dev/console if it is commented out.

custom_item_122.description: GEN001000 - Remote consoles must be disabled or protected from unauthorized access.
custom_item_122.info: The remote console feature provides an additional means of access to the system which could allow unauthorized access if not disabled or properly secured.  With virtualization technologies, remote console access is essential as there is no physical console for virtual machines.  Remote console access must be protected in the same manner as any other remote privileged access method.

custom_item_123.description: GEN001020 - The root account must not be used for direct logins - configured
custom_item_123.info: Direct login with the root account prevents individual user accountability. Acceptable non-routine uses of the root account for direct login are limited to emergency maintenance, the use of single-user mode for maintenance, and situations where individual administrator accounts are not available.
custom_item_123.solution:
Convert the root user into a role.
# usermod -K type=role root

Add the root role to authorized users' logins.
# usermod -R root

custom_item_124.description: GEN001020 - The root account must not be used for direct logins - login report
custom_item_124.info: Direct login with the root account prevents individual user accountability. Acceptable non-routine uses of the root account for direct login are limited to emergency maintenance, the use of single-user mode for maintenance, and situations where individual administrator accounts are not available.
custom_item_124.solution:
Convert the root user into a role.
# usermod -K type=role root

Add the root role to authorized users' logins.
# usermod -R root
custom_item_124.cmd: /usr/bin/last root | /usr/bin/egrep -v "(^wtmp|reboot|^$)" | /usr/bin/head -10 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no root logins found" }'

custom_item_125.description: GEN001060 - The system must log successful and unsuccessful access to the root account - /var/adm/sulog
custom_item_125.info: If successful and unsuccessful logins and logouts are not monitored or recorded, access attempts cannot be tracked.  Without this logging, it may be impossible to track unauthorized access to the system.
custom_item_125.solution:
Update /etc/default/su and set SYSLOG=YES.

Ensure /etc/syslog.conf is configured to log auth.crit messages to capture all failed su attempts.

custom_item_126.description: GEN001060 - The system must log successful and unsuccessful access to the root account - /etc/default/su
custom_item_126.info: If successful and unsuccessful logins and logouts are not monitored or recorded, access attempts cannot be tracked.  Without this logging, it may be impossible to track unauthorized access to the system.
custom_item_126.solution:
Update /etc/default/su and set SYSLOG=YES.

Ensure /etc/syslog.conf is configured to log auth.crit messages to capture all failed su attempts.

custom_item_128.description: GEN001080 - The root shell must be located in the / file system.
custom_item_128.info: To ensure the root shell is available in repair and administrative modes, the root shell must be located in the / file system.
custom_item_128.solution:
Change the root account's shell to one present on the / filesystem. Example:

# usermod -s /sbin/sh root

custom_item_129.description: root has logged in from the network

custom_item_130.description: GEN001100 - Root passwords must never be passed over a network in clear text form.
custom_item_130.info:
If a user accesses the root account (or any account) using an unencrypted connection, the password is passed over the network in clear text form and is subject to interception and misuse.  This is true even if recommended procedures are followed by logging on to a named account and using the su command to access root.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000074, SRG-OS-000520
custom_item_130.solution: Enable SSH on the system and use it for all remote connections used to attain root access.

custom_item_131.description: GEN001120 - The system must not permit root logins using remote access programs such as SSH.
custom_item_131.info: Even though communications are encrypted, an additional layer of security may be gained by extending the policy of not logging directly on as root. In addition, logging in with a user-specific account preserves the audit trail.
custom_item_131.solution: Edit the configuration file and set the PermitRootLogin option to no.

custom_item_132.description: GEN001140 - System files and directories must not have uneven access permissions - /etc/*
custom_item_132.info: Discretionary access control is undermined if users, other than a file owner, have greater access permissions to system files and directories than the owner.
custom_item_132.solution: Change the mode of files with uneven permissions so owners do not have less permission than group or world users.

custom_item_169.description: GEN001260 - System log files must have mode 0640 or less permissive - /var/log
custom_item_169.info: If the system log files are not protected, unauthorized users could change the logged data, eliminating its forensic value.
custom_item_169.solution:
Change the mode of the system log file(s) to 0640 or less permissive.

Procedure:
# chmod '0640' /path/to/system-log-file

NOTE: Do not confuse system log files with audit logs.   Any subsystems that require less stringent permissions must be documented.

custom_item_182.description: GEN001320 - NIS/NIS+/yp files must be owned by root, sys, or bin - /usr/lib/netsvc/yp/*
custom_item_182.info: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are, therefore, critical to system security. custom_item_189.description: GEN001362 - The /etc/resolv.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_189.info: The resolv.conf (or equivalent) file configures the system's DNS resolver.  DNS is used to resolve host names to IP addresses.  If DNS configuration is modified maliciously, host name resolution may fail or return incorrect information.  DNS may be used by a variety of system security functions, such as time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.
custom_item_189.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/resolv.conf file to root.
# chown root /etc/resolv.conf

custom_item_208.description: GEN001394 - The /etc/group file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_208.info: The /etc/group file is critical to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.  The group file contains a list of system groups and associated information.
custom_item_208.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/group
custom_item_208.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/group | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_209.description: GEN001400 - The /etc/shadow (or equivalent) file must be owned by root.
custom_item_209.info: The /etc/shadow file contains the list of local system accounts.  It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.  Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_209.solution:
Change the ownership of the /etc/shadow file.
# chown root /etc/shadow

custom_item_210.description: GEN001410 - The /etc/shadow file (or equivalent) must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_210.info: The /etc/shadow file contains the list of local system accounts.  It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.  The file also contains password hashes which must not be accessible to users other than root.
custom_item_210.solution:
Change the group owner of the /etc/shadow file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/shadow
