custom_item_213.description: GEN001475 - The /etc/group file must not contain any group password hashes.
custom_item_213.info: Group passwords are typically shared and should not be used.  Additionally, if password hashes are readable by non-administrators, the passwords are subject to attack through lookup tables or cryptographic weaknesses in the hashes.
custom_item_213.solution: Edit /etc/group and change the password field to an exclamation point (!) to lock the group password.

custom_item_214.description: GEN001490 - User's home directories must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_214.info: Excessive permissions on home directories allow unauthorized access to user's files.
custom_item_214.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- [user home directory with extended ACL]
custom_item_214.cmd: /usr/bin/awk -F: '{ print $6 }' /etc/passwd | /usr/bin/sort -u | /usr/bin/xargs /usr/bin/ls -lLd | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_215.description: GEN001560 - All files and directories contained in user's home directories must have mode 0750 or less permissive.
custom_item_215.info: Excessive permissions allow unauthorized access to user's files.
custom_item_215.solution:
Change the mode of files and directories within user's home directories to 0750.

Procedure:
# chmod 0750 filename

Document all changes.
custom_item_215.cmd: cat /etc/passwd | egrep -v '^(root|halt|sync|shutdown)' | awk -F: '($7 !="/sbin/nologin" && $7 != "/bin/false") { print $1 " " $6 }' | while read user dir; do if [ ! -d "$dir" ]; then echo "The home directory ($dir) of user $user does not exist.";else dirperm=`ls -ld $dir | cut -f1 -d" "`;if [ `echo $dirperm | cut -c6` != "-" ]; then echo "Group Write permission set on the home directory ($dir) of user $user";fi;if [ `echo $dirperm | cut -c8` != "-" ]; then echo "Other Read permission set on the home directory ($dir) of user $user";fi;if [ `echo $dirperm | cut -c9` != "-" ]; then echo "Other Write permission set on the home directory ($dir) of user $user";fi;if [ `echo $dirperm | cut -c10` != "-" ]; then echo "Other Execute permission set on the home directory ($dir) of user $user";fi;fi;done | /bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR==0) print "All home directories have proper permissions" }'
custom_item_215.expect: All home directories have proper permissions

custom_item_216.description: GEN001580 - All run control scripts must have mode 0755 or less permissive - /etc/rc*
custom_item_216.info: If the startup files are writable by other users, they could modify the startup files to insert malicious commands into the startup files.
custom_item_216.solution:
Ensure all system startup files have mode 0755 or less permissive. Examine the rc files, and all files in the rc1.d (rc2.d, and so on) directories, and in the /etc/init.d and /lib/svc/method directories to ensure they are not world-writable. If they are world-writable, use the chmod command to correct the vulnerability and to research why.

Procedure:
# chmod go-w

custom_item_220.description: GEN001600 - Run control scripts executable search paths must contain only authorized paths - /etc/init.d/*
custom_item_220.info: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, two consecutive colons, or a single period, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_220.solution:
Edit the run control script and remove the relative path entries from the executable search path variable that are not documented with the ISSO.

Edit the run control script and remove any empty entry that is defined.

custom_item_262.description: GEN001820 - All skeleton files and directories (typically in /etc/skel) must be owned by root - /etc/skel
custom_item_262.info: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files.  Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_262.solution:
Change the ownership of skeleton files with incorrect mode.
# chown root

custom_item_263.solution:

custom_item_264.description: GEN001830 - All skeleton files (typically in /etc/skel) must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_264.info: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files.
custom_item_264.solution:
Change the group owner of the skeleton file to root.

Procedure:
# chgrp/etc/skel/[skeleton file]

custom_item_265.description: GEN001840 - All global initialization files executable search paths must contain only authorized paths - /etc/profile
custom_item_265.info: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, two consecutive colons, or a single period, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.
custom_item_265.solution:
Edit the global initialization file(s) with PATH variables containing relative paths and remove any relative path form the PATH variables that have not been documented with the ISSO.

Edit the global initialization file(s) and remove any empty entry that is defined.

custom_item_286.description: GEN001880 - All local initialization files must have mode 0740 or less permissive - .login
custom_item_286.info: Local initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon login.  Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.
custom_item_286.solution:
Ensure user startup files have permissions of 0740 or more restrictive.  Examine each user's home directory and verify all file names beginning with '.' have access permissions of 0740 or more restrictive.  If they do not, use the chmod command to correct the vulnerability.

Procedure:
# chmod 0740 .filename

NOTE: The period is part of the file name and is required.

custom_item_302.description: GEN001980 - The .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, shosts.equiv, /etc/passwd, /etc/shadow, and/or /etc/group files must not contain a plus (+) without defining entries for NIS+ netgroups - /etc/passwd
custom_item_302.info: A plus (+) in system accounts' files causes the system to lookup the specified entry using NIS.  If the system is not using NIS, no such entries should exist.
custom_item_302.solution: Edit the .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, shosts.equiv, /etc/passwd, /etc/shadow, and/or /etc/group files and remove entries containing a plus (+).

custom_item_309.description: GEN002000 - There must be no .netrc files on the system.
custom_item_309.info: Unencrypted passwords for remote FTP servers may be stored in .netrc files.  Policy requires passwords be encrypted in storage and not used in access scripts.

custom_item_310.description: GEN002020 - All .rhosts, .shosts, or host.equiv files must only contain trusted host-user pairs.
custom_item_310.info:
If these files are not properly configured, they could allow malicious access by unknown malicious users from untrusted hosts who could compromise the system.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_310.solution: If possible, remove the .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, and shosts.equiv files.  If the files are required, remove any content from the files except for necessary host-user pairs.
custom_item_310.cmd: /usr/bin/awk -F: '{print $6}' /etc/passwd | /usr/bin/xargs -iDIR ls DIR/.rhosts DIR/.shosts /etc/hosts.equiv /etc/ssh/shosts.equiv 2>/dev/null | /usr/bin/sort -u 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no files found" }'

custom_item_311.description: GEN002040 - There must be no .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system.
custom_item_311.info: The .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, and shosts.equiv files are used to configure host-based authentication for individual users or the system.  Host-based authentication is not sufficient for preventing unauthorized access to the system.
custom_item_311.solution: Remove the .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, and/or shosts.equiv files.
custom_item_311.cmd: /usr/bin/awk -F: '{print $6}' /etc/passwd | /usr/bin/xargs -iDIR ls DIR/.rhosts DIR/.shosts /etc/hosts.equiv /etc/ssh/shosts.equiv 2>/dev/null| /usr/bin/sort -u 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no files found" }'

custom_item_312.description: GEN002060 - All .rhosts, .shosts, .netrc, or hosts.equiv files must be accessible by only root or the owner - .rhosts perms
custom_item_312.info: If these files are accessible by users other than root or the owner, they could be used by a malicious user to set up a system compromise.
custom_item_312.solution: Ensure the permission for these files is set at 600 or less and the owner is the owner of the home directory that it is in. These files, outside of home directories (other than hosts.equiv in /etc and shosts.equiv in /etc/ssh; both are owned by root), have no meaning.

custom_item_317.description: GEN002100 - The .rhosts file must not be supported in PAM.
custom_item_317.info: The .rhosts files are used to specify a list of hosts that are permitted remote access to a particular account without authenticating.  The use of such a mechanism defeats strong identification and authentication requirements.
custom_item_317.solution: Edit /etc/pam.conf and remove the reference(s) to the rhosts_auth module.

custom_item_318.description: GEN009120 - The system, if capable, must be configured to require the use of a CAC, PIV compliant hardware token, or Alternate Logon Token (ALT) for authentication.
custom_item_318.info:
In accordance with CTO 07-015 PKI authentication is required. This provides stronger, two-factor authentication than using a username/password.

NOTE: The following are exempt from this, however, they must meet all password requirements and must be documented with the IAO:

- Stand-alone systems.
- Application Accounts.
- Students or unpaid employees (such as, interns) who are not eligible to receive or not in receipt of a CAC, PIV, or ALT.
- Warfighters and support personnel located at operational tactical locations conducting wartime operations that are not collocated with RAPIDS workstations to issue CAC; are not eligible for CAC or do not have the capability to use ALT.
- Test systems that have an Interim Approval to Test (IATT) and provide protection via separate VPN, firewall, or security measures preventing access to network and system components from outside the protection boundary documented in the IATT.

NOTE: Nessus has not performed this check. Please review the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_318.solution: Consult vendor documentation to determine the procedures necessary for configuring CAC authentication. Configure all accounts required by policy to use CAC authentication.

custom_item_319.description: GEN002230 - All shell files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_319.info: Shells with world/group write permissions give the ability to maliciously modify the shell to obtain unauthorized access.
custom_item_319.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- [shell]
custom_item_319.cmd: /usr/bin/cat /etc/shells 2>/dev/null | /usr/bin/xargs -n1 ls -lLd | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_320.description: GEN002320 - Audio devices must have mode 0660 or less permissive - /dev/audio*
custom_item_320.info: Globally accessible  audio and video devices have proven to be security hazards.  There is software that can activate system microphones and video devices connected to user workstations and/or X terminals.  Once the microphone has been activated, it is possible to eavesdrop on otherwise private conversations without the victim being aware of it.  This action effectively changes the user's microphone to a bugging device.
custom_item_320.solution:
Change the mode of the audio device.
# chmod -R 0660 /dev/audio

custom_item_322.description: GEN002330 - Audio devices must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_322.info: File system ACLs can provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.
custom_item_322.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /dev/audio
custom_item_322.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /dev/audio* /dev/sound/* | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_325.description: GEN002360 - Audio devices must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin - /dev/audio*

custom_item_327.description: GEN002420 - Removable media, remote file systems, and any file system that does not contain approved setuid files must be mounted with the 'nosuid' option - /etc/vfstab
custom_item_327.info:
The 'nosuid' mount option causes the system to not execute setuid files with owner privileges.  This option must be used for mounting any file system that does not contain approved setuid files.  Executing setuid files from untrusted file systems, or file systems that do not contain approved setuid files, increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_327.solution:
Use the following procedure for UFS filesystems.
Edit /etc/vfstab and add the 'nosuid' mount option to any user filesystem (such as /export/home) or filesystems mounted from removable media or network shares.

Use the following procedure for ZFS filesystems.
# zfs setuid = off < file system >
custom_item_327.cmd: /usr/bin/cat /etc/vfstab 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no lines found" }'

custom_item_328.description: GEN002420 - Removable media, remote file systems, and any file system that does not contain approved setuid files must be mounted with the 'nosuid' option - zfs get
custom_item_328.info:
The 'nosuid' mount option causes the system to not execute setuid files with owner privileges.  This option must be used for mounting any file system that does not contain approved setuid files.  Executing setuid files from untrusted file systems, or file systems that do not contain approved setuid files, increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_328.solution:
Use the following procedure for UFS filesystems.
Edit /etc/vfstab and add the 'nosuid' mount option to any user filesystem (such as /export/home) or filesystems mounted from removable media or network shares.

Use the following procedure for ZFS filesystems.
# zfs setuid = off < file system >
custom_item_328.cmd: /usr/sbin/zfs get setuid 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no lines found" }'

custom_item_329.description: GEN002520 - All public directories must be owned by root or an application account.
custom_item_329.info:
If a public directory has the sticky bit set and is not owned by a privileged UID, unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.

The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage (e.g., /tmp) and for directories requiring global read/write access.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_329.solution:
Change the owner of public directories to root or an application account.

Procedure:
# chown root /tmp

(Replace root with an application user and/or /tmp with another public directory as necessary.)
custom_item_329.cmd: /usr/bin/find / -type d -perm -1002 ! -user root -exec /usr/bin/ls -lLd {} \\; 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no directories found" }'

custom_item_330.description: GEN002540 - All public directories must be group-owned by root or an application group.
custom_item_330.info:
If a public directory has the sticky bit set and is not group-owned by a system GID, unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.

The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage (e.g., /tmp) and for directories requiring global read/write access.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_330.solution:
Change the group ownership of the public directory.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /tmp

(Replace root with a different system group and/or /tmp with a different public directory as necessary.)
custom_item_330.cmd: /usr/bin/find / -type d -perm -1002 ! \\( -group root -o -group sys \\) -exec /usr/bin/ls -lLd {} \\; 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no directories found" }'

custom_item_331.description: GEN002560 - The system and user default umask must be 077 - /etc/default/login
custom_item_331.info: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files.  An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive.  Although umask can be represented as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0.  This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the user defaults for each account on the system.
custom_item_331.solution:
Edit the /etc/default/login file for Solaris. Set the variable UMASK=077.

Edit local and global initialization files containing 'umask' and change them to use '077'.

custom_item_335.description: GEN002640 - Default system accounts must be disabled or removed.
custom_item_335.info: Vendor accounts and software may contain backdoors allowing unauthorized access to the system.  These backdoors are common knowledge and present a threat to system security if the account is not disabled.
custom_item_335.solution:
Lock the default system account(s).
# passwd -l

custom_item_337.description: GEN002660 - Auditing must be implemented. - perzone

custom_item_338.info: Without auditing, individual system accesses cannot be tracked and malicious activity cannot be detected and traced back to an individual account.
custom_item_338.solution: Use /etc/security/bsmconv to enable auditing on the system.

custom_item_339.description: GEN002660 - Auditing must be implemented - Running Process
custom_item_339.info: Without auditing, individual system accesses cannot be tracked and malicious activity cannot be detected and traced back to an individual account.
custom_item_339.solution: Use /etc/security/bsmconv to enable auditing on the system.

custom_item_340.description: GEN002680 - System audit logs must be owned by root.
custom_item_340.info: Failure to give ownership of system audit log files to root provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information.
custom_item_340.solution:
Change the ownership of the audit log file(s).

Procedure:
# chown root

custom_item_341.description: GEN002690 - System audit logs must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_341.info: Sensitive system and user information could provide a malicious user with enough information to penetrate further into the system.
custom_item_341.solution:
Change the group ownership of the audit log file(s).

Procedure:
# chgrp root

custom_item_342.description: GEN002700 - System audit logs must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_342.info: If a user can write to the audit logs, audit trails can be modified or destroyed and system intrusion may not be detected.  System audit logs are those files generated from the audit system and do not include activity, error, or other log files created by application software.
custom_item_342.solution:
Change the mode of the audit log directories/files.
# chmod 0750# chmod 0640

custom_item_343.description: GEN002710 - All system audit files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_343.info: If a user can write to the audit logs, then audit trails can be modified or destroyed and system intrusion may not be detected.
custom_item_343.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- [audit file]
custom_item_343.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd @AUDIT_DIR@/* | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_363.description: GEN002719 - The audit system must alert the SA in the event of an audit processing failure.
custom_item_363.info:
An accurate and current audit trail is essential for maintaining
a record of system activity. If the system fails, the SA must be notified and must take prompt
action to correct the problem.

Minimally, the system must log this event and the SA will receive this notification during the
daily system log review. If feasible, active alerting (such as email or paging) should be
employed consistent with the site's established operations management systems and procedures.
custom_item_363.solution:
Add an audit_warn alias to /etc/mail/aliases that will forward to designated system administrator(s).

# vi /etc/mail/aliases

Put the updated aliases file into service.

# newaliases

custom_item_364.description: GEN002720 - The audit system must be configured to audit failed attempts to access files and programs.
custom_item_364.info: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.
custom_item_364.solution:
Edit /etc/security/audit_control and add the fr or -fr flags to the flags list.
Load the new audit configuration.
# auditconfig -conf

custom_item_365.description: GEN002730 - The audit system must alert the SA when the audit storage volume approaches its capacity - minfree
custom_item_365.info:
An accurate and current audit trail is essential for maintaining a record of system activity.  If the system fails, the SA must be notified and must take prompt action to correct the problem.

Minimally, the system must log this event and the SA will receive this notification during the daily system log review.  If feasible, active alerting (such as email or paging) should be employed consistent with the site's established operations management systems and procedures.
custom_item_365.solution:
If necessary, add an audit_warn alias to /etc/mail/aliases that will forward to designated system administrator(s).

# vi /etc/mail/aliases

Put the updated aliases file into service.

# newaliases

If necessary, add or update the minfree: parameter in /etc/security/audit_control.

# vi /etc/security/audit_control

Ensure the minfree value is greater than zero and less than 100.

custom_item_366.description: GEN002730 - The audit system must alert the SA when the audit storage volume approaches its capacity - audit_warn
custom_item_366.info:
An accurate and current audit trail is essential for maintaining a record of system activity.  If the system fails, the SA must be notified and must take prompt action to correct the problem.

Minimally, the system must log this event and the SA will receive this notification during the daily system log review.  If feasible, active alerting (such as email or paging) should be employed consistent with the site's established operations management systems and procedures.
custom_item_366.solution:
If necessary, add an audit_warn alias to /etc/mail/aliases that will forward to designated system administrator(s).

# vi /etc/mail/aliases

Put the updated aliases file into service.

# newaliases

If necessary, add or update the minfree: parameter in /etc/security/audit_control.

# vi /etc/security/audit_control

Ensure the minfree value is greater than zero and less than 100.

custom_item_388.description: GEN002825 - The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules.
custom_item_388.info: Actions concerning dynamic kernel modules must be recorded as they are substantial events.  Dynamic kernel modules can increase the attack surface of a system.  A malicious kernel module can be used to substantially alter the functioning of a system, often with the purpose of hiding a compromise from the SA.
custom_item_388.solution: Edit /etc/security/audit_control and add the as flag to the flag parameter.

custom_item_389.description: GEN002860 - Audit logs must be rotated daily.
custom_item_389.info:
Rotate audit logs daily to preserve audit file system space and to conform to the DoD/DISA requirement.  If it is not rotated daily and moved to another location, then there is more of a chance for the compromise of audit data by malicious users.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_389.solution: Configure a cron job or other automated process to rotate the audit logs on a daily basis.
custom_item_389.cmd: /usr/bin/egrep -v '^#' /var/spool/cron/crontabs/root 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no jobs found" }'

custom_item_390.description: GEN002870 - The system must be configured to send audit records to a remote audit server - NFS
custom_item_390.info:
Audit records contain evidence that can be used in the investigation of compromised systems.  To prevent this evidence from compromise, it must be sent to a separate system continuously. Methods for sending audit records include, but are not limited to, system audit tools used to send logs directly to another host or through the system's syslog service to another host.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_390.solution:
Update the /etc/security/audit_control file to save audit records to a remote NFS mount.

dir:OR

If the /usr/lib/security/audit_syslog.so* exists, update the /etc/security/audit_control file to send all audit records to syslog and update /etc/syslog.conf to send all audit messages to a remote server.

/etc/security/audit_control:
plugin:name=audit_syslog.so.1; p_flags=all

/etc/syslog.conf:
audit.* @

custom_item_395.description: GEN002980 - The cron.allow file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_395.info: A cron.allow file that is readable and/or writable by other than root could allow potential intruders and malicious users to use the file contents to help discern information, such as who is allowed to execute cron programs, which could be harmful to overall system and network security.
custom_item_395.solution:
Change the mode of the cron.allow file to 0600.

Procedure:
# chmod 0600 /etc/cron.d/cron.allow

custom_item_396.description: GEN002990 - The cron.allow file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_396.info: A cron.allow file that is readable and/or writable by other than root could allow potential intruders and malicious users to use the file contents to help discern information, such as who is allowed to execute cron programs, which could be harmful to overall system and network security.
custom_item_396.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/cron.allow
custom_item_396.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/cron.d/cron.allow | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_397.description: GEN003000 - Cron must not execute group-writable or world-writable programs.
custom_item_397.info:
If cron executes group-writable or world-writable programs, there is a possibility that unauthorized users could manipulate the programs with malicious intent.  This could compromise system and network security.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_397.solution:
Remove the world-writable and group-writable permissions from the cron program file(s) identified.
# chmod go-w

custom_item_398.description: GEN003020 - Cron must not execute programs in, or subordinate to, world-writable directories.
custom_item_398.info:
If cron programs are located in or subordinate to world-writable directories, they become vulnerable to removal and replacement by malicious users or system intruders.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_398.solution:
Remove the world-writable permission from the cron program directories identified.

Procedure:
# chmod o-w

custom_item_399.description: GEN003040 - Crontabs must be owned by root or the crontab creator.
custom_item_399.info: To protect the integrity of scheduled system jobs and prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be secured.
custom_item_399.solution:
Change the crontab owner to root or the crontab creator.
# chown root
custom_item_399.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lL /var/spool/cron/crontabs/ | /usr/bin/awk '$3 != $9 && $3 != "root" { print "/var/spool/cron/crontabs/"$9,$3":"$4; n++ } END { if (!n) print "no crontab found" }'

custom_item_400.description: GEN003050 - Crontab files must be group-owned by root, sys, or the crontab creator's primary group.
custom_item_400.info: To protect the integrity of scheduled system jobs and prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be secured.
custom_item_400.solution:
Change the group owner of the crontab file to root, sys, or the crontab's primary group.
Procedure:
# chgrp root [crontab file]
custom_item_400.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lL /var/spool/cron/crontabs/ | /usr/bin/awk '$4 != $9 && $4 !~ /^(root|sys)$/ { print "/var/spool/cron/crontabs/"$9,$3":"$4; n++ } END { if (!n) print "no crontab found" }'

custom_item_402.description: GEN003060 - Default system accounts (with the exception of root) must not be listed in the cron.allow file or must be included in the cron.deny file, if cron.allow does not exist.
custom_item_402.info: To centralize the management of privileged account crontabs, of the default system accounts, only root may have a crontab.
custom_item_402.solution: Remove default system accounts (such as bin, sys, adm, or others) from the cron.allow file if it exists, or add those accounts to the cron.deny file.
custom_item_402.cmd: /usr/bin/logins -s | /usr/bin/cut -f1 -d' ' | /usr/bin/cat /etc/cron.d/cron.allow - | /usr/bin/sort | /usr/bin/uniq -d | /usr/bin/grep -v root 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no accounts found" }'

custom_item_403.description: GEN003060 - Default system accounts (with the exception of root) must not be listed in the cron.allow file or must be included in the cron.deny file, if cron.allow does not exist.
custom_item_403.info: To centralize the management of privileged account crontabs, of the default system accounts, only root may have a crontab.
custom_item_403.solution: Remove default system accounts (such as bin, sys, adm, or others) from the cron.allow file if it exists, or add those accounts to the cron.deny file.
custom_item_403.cmd: /usr/bin/logins -sto | /usr/bin/cut -f1 -d: | /usr/bin/egrep -v -f /etc/cron.d/cron.deny /dev/stdin 2>&1 |/usr/bin/grep -v 'root' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no accounts found" }'

custom_item_404.description: GEN003080 - Crontab files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_404.info: To protect the integrity of scheduled system jobs and prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be secured.
custom_item_404.solution:
Change the mode of the crontab files.
# chmod 0600 /var/spool/cron/crontabs/*

custom_item_405.description: GEN003090 - Crontab files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_405.info: To protect the integrity of scheduled system jobs and to prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be secured.  ACLs on crontab files may provide unauthorized access to the files.
custom_item_405.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- [crontab file]
custom_item_405.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /var/spool/cron/crontabs/* | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_406.description: GEN003100 - Cron and crontab directories must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
custom_item_406.info: To protect the integrity of scheduled system jobs and to prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be secured.
custom_item_406.solution:
Change the mode of the crontab directory.
# chmod 0755 /var/spool/cron/crontabs

custom_item_407.description: GEN003110 - Cron and crontab directories must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_407.info: To protect the integrity of scheduled system jobs and to prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be secured.  ACLs on cron and crontab directories may provide unauthorized access to these directories.  Unauthorized modifications to these directories or their contents may result in the addition of unauthorized cron jobs or deny service to authorized cron jobs.
custom_item_407.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the directory.
# chmod A- /var/spool/cron/crontabs/
custom_item_407.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /var/spool/cron/crontabs | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_408.description: GEN003120 - Cron and crontab directories must be owned by root or bin.
custom_item_408.info: Incorrect ownership of the cron or crontab directories could permit unauthorized users the ability to alter cron jobs and run automated jobs as privileged users.  Failure to give ownership of cron or crontab directories to root or to bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_408.solution:
Change the owner of the crontab directory.
# chown root /var/spool/cron/crontabs

custom_item_409.description: GEN003140 - Cron and crontab directories must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin.
custom_item_409.info: To protect the integrity of scheduled system jobs and to prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be secured.  Failure to give group-ownership of cron or crontab directories to a system group provides the designated group and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_409.solution:
Change the group owner of the crontab directories to root, sys, or bin.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /var/spool/cron/crontabs

custom_item_410.description: GEN003160 - Cron logging must be implemented - log exists
custom_item_410.info: Cron logging can be used to trace the successful or unsuccessful execution of cron jobs.  It can also be used to spot intrusions into the use of the cron facility by unauthorized and malicious users.

custom_item_411.description: GEN003160 - Cron logging must be implemented - configured
custom_item_411.info: Cron logging can be used to trace the successful or unsuccessful execution of cron jobs.  It can also be used to spot intrusions into the use of the cron facility by unauthorized and malicious users.

custom_item_412.description: GEN003180 - The cronlog file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_412.info: Cron logs contain reports of scheduled system activities and must be protected from unauthorized access or manipulation.
custom_item_412.solution:
Change the mode of the cron log file.
# chmod 0600 /var/cron/log

custom_item_413.description: GEN003190 - The cron log files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_413.info: Cron logs contain reports of scheduled system activities and must be protected from unauthorized access or manipulation.
custom_item_413.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /var/cron/log

custom_item_414.description: GEN003200 - The cron.deny file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_414.info: If file permissions for cron.deny are more permissive than 0600, sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users.
custom_item_414.solution:
Change the mode of the cron.deny file.
# chmod 0600 /etc/cron.d/cron.deny

custom_item_415.description: GEN003210 - The cron.deny file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_415.info: If file permissions for cron.deny are more permissive than 0700, sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users.
custom_item_415.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/cron.d/cron.deny
custom_item_415.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/cron.d/cron.deny | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_416.description: GEN003220 - Cron programs must not set the umask to a value less restrictive than 077.
custom_item_416.info:
The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files.  An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive.  Although umask is often represented as a 4-digit octal number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_416.solution: Edit cron script files and modify the umask to 077.

custom_item_417.description: GEN003240 - The cron.allow file must be owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_417.info: If the owner of the cron.allow file is not set to root, bin, or sys, the possibility exists for an unauthorized user to view or to edit sensitive information.

custom_item_418.description: GEN003245 - The at.allow file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_418.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  Unauthorized modification of the at.allow file could result in Denial of Service to authorized at users and the granting of the ability to run at jobs to unauthorized users.
custom_item_418.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/cron.d/at.allow
custom_item_418.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/cron.d/at.allow | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_419.description: GEN003250 - The cron.allow file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_419.info: If the group of the cron.allow is not set to root, bin, or sys, the possibility exists for an unauthorized user to view or edit the list of users permitted to use cron.  Unauthorized modification of this file could cause Denial of Service to authorized cron users or provide unauthorized users with the ability to run cron jobs.
custom_item_419.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/cron.d/cron.allow

custom_item_420.description: GEN003252 - The at.deny file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_420.info: The at daemon control files restrict access to scheduled job manipulation and must be protected.  Unauthorized modification of the at.deny file could result in Denial of Service to authorized at users or provide unauthorized users with the ability to run at jobs.
custom_item_420.solution:
Change the mode of the file.
# chmod 0600 /etc/cron.d/at.deny

custom_item_421.info: The 'at' daemon control files restrict access to scheduled job manipulation and must be protected.  Unauthorized modification of the at.deny file could result in Denial of Service to authorized 'at' users or provide unauthorized users with the ability to run 'at' jobs.

Remove the extended ACL from the file.

custom_item_422.description: GEN003260 - The cron.deny file must be owned by root, bin, or sys.

Change the ownership of the cron.deny file to root, sys, or bin.

custom_item_423.description: GEN003270 - The cron.deny file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_423.info: Cron daemon control files restrict the scheduling of automated tasks and must be protected.  Unauthorized modification of the cron.deny file could result in Denial of Service to authorized cron users or could provide unauthorized users with the ability to run cron jobs.

Change the group ownership of the file to root, sys, or bin.

custom_item_427.description: GEN003300 - The at.deny file must not be empty if it exists.
custom_item_427.info: On some systems, if there is no at.allow file and there is an empty at.deny file, then the system assumes everyone has permission to use the at facility.  This could create an insecure setting in the case of malicious users or system intruders.
custom_item_427.solution: Add appropriate users to the at.deny file, or remove the empty at.deny file if an at.allow file exists.

custom_item_429.description: GEN003320 - Default system accounts (with the exception of root) must not be listed in the at.allow file or must be included in the at.deny file if the at.allow file does not exist.
custom_item_429.info: Default accounts, such as bin, sys, adm, uucp, daemon, and others, should never have access to the at facility.  This would create a possible vulnerability open to intruders or malicious users.
custom_item_429.solution: Remove the default accounts (such as bin, sys, adm, and others) from the at.allow file.
custom_item_429.cmd: /usr/bin/logins -s | /usr/bin/cut -f1 -d' ' | /usr/bin/cat /etc/cron.d/at.allow - | /usr/bin/sort | /usr/bin/uniq -d | /usr/bin/grep -v root 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no accounts found" }'

custom_item_430.description: GEN003320 - Default system accounts (with the exception of root) must not be listed in the at.allow file or must be included in the at.deny file if the at.allow file does not exist.
custom_item_430.info: Default accounts, such as bin, sys, adm, uucp, daemon, and others, should never have access to the at facility.  This would create a possible vulnerability open to intruders or malicious users.
custom_item_430.solution: Remove the default accounts (such as bin, sys, adm, and others) from the at.allow file.
custom_item_430.cmd: /usr/bin/logins -sto | /usr/bin/cut -f1 -d: | /usr/bin/egrep -v -f /etc/cron.d/at.deny /dev/stdin 2>&1 |/usr/bin/grep -v 'root' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no accounts found" }'

custom_item_431.description: GEN003340 - The at.allow file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_431.info: Permissions more permissive than 0600 (read and write for the owner) may allow unauthorized or malicious access to the at.allow and/or at.deny files.
custom_item_431.solution:
Change the mode of the at.allow file.
# chmod 0600 /etc/cron.d/at.allow

custom_item_432.description: GEN003360 - The 'at' daemon must not execute group-writable or world-writable programs - at daemon must not execute group-writable or world-writable programs.
custom_item_432.info:
If the 'at' facility executes world-writable or group-writable programs, it is possible for the programs to be accidentally or maliciously changed or replaced without the owner's intent or knowledge.  This would cause a system security breach.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_432.solution:
Remove group-write and world-write permissions from files executed by 'at' jobs.
Procedure:
# chmod go-w

custom_item_433.description: GEN003380 - The 'at' daemon must not execute programs in, or subordinate to, world-writable directories - at daemon must not execute programs in, or subordinate to, world-writable directories.
custom_item_433.info:
If 'at' programs are located in or subordinate to world-writable directories, they become vulnerable to removal and replacement by malicious users or system intruders.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

Remove the world-writable permission from directories containing programs executed by 'at'.

custom_item_434.description: GEN003400 - The 'at' directory must have mode 0755 or less permissive - at directory must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
custom_item_434.info: If the 'at' directory has a mode more permissive than 0755, unauthorized users could be allowed to view or to edit files containing sensitive information within the 'at' directory.  Unauthorized modifications could result in Denial of Service to authorized 'at' jobs.

custom_item_438.description: GEN003440 - 'At' jobs must not set the umask to a value less restrictive than 077 - At jobs must not set the umask to a value less restrictive than 077.
custom_item_438.info:
The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files.  An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive.  Although umask is often represented as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_438.solution: Edit 'at' jobs or referenced scripts to remove umask commands setting umask to a value less restrictive than 077.

custom_item_443.description: GEN003500 - Process core dumps must be disabled unless needed - COREADM
custom_item_443.info: Process core dumps contain the memory in use by the process when it crashed.  Process core dump files can be of significant size and their use can result in file systems filling to capacity, which may result in Denial of Service.  Process core dumps can be useful for software debugging.
custom_item_443.solution:
Change the process core dump configuration.
# coreadm -d global
# coreadm -d process
# coreadm -d global-setid
# coreadm -d proc-setid
# coreadm -d log

Edit /etc/system and remove the coredumpsize parameter.

custom_item_444.description: GEN003500 - Process core dumps must be disabled unless needed - sys:coredumpsize
custom_item_444.info: Process core dumps contain the memory in use by the process when it crashed.  Process core dump files can be of significant size and their use can result in file systems filling to capacity, which may result in Denial of Service.  Process core dumps can be useful for software debugging.
custom_item_444.solution:
Change the process core dump configuration.
# coreadm -d global
# coreadm -d process
# coreadm -d global-setid
# coreadm -d proc-setid
# coreadm -d log

Edit /etc/system and remove the coredumpsize parameter.

custom_item_445.description: GEN003501 - The system must be configured to store any process core dumps in a specific, centralized directory.
custom_item_445.info: Specifying a centralized location for core file creation allows for the centralized protection of core files.  Process core dumps contain the memory in use by the process when it crashed.  Any data the process was handling may be contained in the core file, and it must be protected accordingly.  If process core dump creation is not configured to use a centralized directory, core dumps may be created in a directory that does not have appropriate ownership or permissions configured, which could result in unauthorized access to the core dumps.
custom_item_445.solution:
Change the core file pattern.
# coreadm -g /var/core/core.%f.%p

Then:
# coreadm -u
In order to force a reload of the configuration.

custom_item_446.description: GEN003502 - The centralized process core dump data directory must be owned by root.
custom_item_446.info: Process core dumps contain the memory in use by the process when it crashed.  Any data the process was handling may be contained in the core file, and it must be protected accordingly.  If the centralized process core dump data directory is not owned by root, the core dumps contained in the directory may be subject to unauthorized access.
custom_item_446.solution:
Change the owner of the core file directory.
# chown root [core file directory]

custom_item_447.description: GEN003503 - The centralized process core dump data directory must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_447.info: Process core dumps contain the memory in use by the process when it crashed.  Any data the process was handling may be contained in the core file, and it must be protected accordingly.  If the centralized process core dump data directory is not group-owned by a system group, the core dumps contained in the directory may be subject to unauthorized access.
custom_item_447.solution:
Change the group-owner of the core file directory to root, bin, or sys.
Example: # chgrp root [core file directory]

custom_item_448.description: GEN003504 - The centralized process core dump data directory must have mode 0700 or less permissive.
custom_item_448.info: Process core dumps contain the memory in use by the process when it crashed.  Any data the process was handling may be contained in the core file, and it must be protected accordingly.  If the process core dump data directory has a mode more permissive than 0700, unauthorized users may be able to view or to modify sensitive information contained any process core dumps in the directory.
custom_item_448.solution:
Change the mode of the core file directory.
# chmod 0700 [core file directory]

custom_item_449.description: GEN003505 - The centralized process core dump data directory must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_449.info: Process core dumps contain the memory in use by the process when it crashed.  Any data the process was handling may be contained in the core file, and it must be protected accordingly.  If the process core dump data directory has an extended ACL, unauthorized users may be able to view or to modify sensitive information contained any process core dumps in the directory.
custom_item_449.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the directory.
# chmod A- [core file directory]
custom_item_449.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /var/core | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_450.description: GEN003510 - Kernel core dumps must be disabled unless needed.
custom_item_450.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash.  Kernel core dumps may consume a considerable amount of disk space and may result in Denial of Service by exhausting the available space on the target file system.  The kernel core dump process may increase the amount of time a system is unavailable due to a crash.  Kernel core dumps can be useful for kernel debugging.

custom_item_451.description: GEN003520 - The kernel core dump data directory must be owned by root.
custom_item_451.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash.  As the system memory may contain sensitive information, it must be protected accordingly. If the kernel core dump data directory is not owned by root, the core dumps contained in the directory may be subject to unauthorized access.
custom_item_451.solution:
Change the owner of the kernel core dump data directory to root.
# chown root /var/crash

custom_item_452.description: GEN003521 - The kernel core dump data directory must be group-owned by root.
custom_item_452.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash.  As the system memory may contain sensitive information, it must be protected accordingly.  If the kernel core dump data directory is not group-owned by a system group, the core dumps contained in the directory may be subject to unauthorized access.
custom_item_452.solution:
Change the group-owner of the kernel core dump data directory.
# chgrp root [kernel core dump data directory]

custom_item_453.description: GEN003522 - The kernel core dump data directory must have mode 0700 or less permissive.
custom_item_453.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash.  As the system memory may contain sensitive information, it must be protected accordingly.  If the mode of the kernel core dump data directory is more permissive than 0700, unauthorized users may be able to view or to modify kernel core dump data files.
custom_item_453.solution:
Change the group-owner of the kernel core dump data directory.
# chmod 0700 [kernel core dump data directory]

custom_item_454.description: GEN003523 - The kernel core dump data directory must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_454.info: Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash.  As the system memory may contain sensitive information, it must be protected accordingly.  If there is an extended ACL for the kernel core dump data directory, unauthorized users may be able to view or to modify kernel core dump data files.
custom_item_454.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- [kernel core dump directory]
custom_item_454.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd @KERNEL_DIR@ | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_455.description: GEN003580 - The system must use initial TCP sequence numbers most resistant to sequence number guessing attacks.
custom_item_455.info: One use of initial TCP sequence numbers is to verify bidirectional communication between two hosts, which provides some protection against spoofed source addresses being used by the connection originator.  If the initial TCP sequence numbers for a host can be determined by an attacker, it may be possible to establish a TCP connection from a spoofed source address without bidirectional communication.
custom_item_455.solution: Edit /etc/default/inetinit and set the TCP_STRONG_ISS parameter to 2.

custom_item_456.description: GEN003600 - The system must not forward IPv4 source-routed packets.
custom_item_456.info: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures.  This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when IPv4 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
custom_item_456.solution:
Configure the system to not forward IPv4 source-routed packets.
Procedure:
# ndd /dev/ip ip_forward_src_routed 0

This command must also be added to a system startup script.

custom_item_458.description: GEN003601 - TCP backlog queue sizes must be set appropriately - dladm show-link
custom_item_458.info:
To provide some mitigation to TCP DoS attacks, the TCP backlog queue sizes must be set to at least 1280 or in accordance with product-specific guidelines.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

Procedure:

# ndd -set /dev/tcp tcp_conn_req_max_q 1024

custom_item_461.description: GEN003602 - The system must not process ICMP timestamp requests.

custom_item_469.description: GEN003606 - The system must prevent local applications from generating source-routed packets - lsrr
custom_item_469.info: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures.
custom_item_469.solution:
Edit /etc/ipf/ipf.conf and add rules to block outgoing source-routed packets, such as:

block out log quick all with opt lsrr
block out log quick all with opt ssrr

Reload the IPF rules.
Procedure:

# ipf -Fa -A -f /etc/ipf/ipf.conf

custom_item_474.description: GEN003608 - Proxy ARP must not be enabled on the system.
custom_item_474.info: Proxy ARP allows a system to respond to ARP requests on one interface on behalf of hosts connected to another interface.  If this function is enabled when not required, addressing information may be leaked between the attached network segments.
custom_item_474.solution:
Remove non-local published ARP entries from the system.

Procedure:
# arp -dCheck system initialization files for any commands creating published ARP entries (such as 'arp -spub' or 'arp -f') and removing them.
custom_item_474.cmd: /usr/sbin/arp -an | /usr/bin/awk '$4 ~ /P/ { print; n++ } END { if (!n) print "no proxy arp found" }'

custom_item_475.description: GEN003609 - The system must ignore IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.
custom_item_475.info: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated.  An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.
custom_item_475.solution:
Configure the system to not accept IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.

Procedure:
# ndd -set /dev/ip ip_ignore_redirect 1

This command must also be added to a system startup script.

custom_item_479.description: GEN003611 - The system must log martian packets - block in ip
custom_item_479.info: Martian packets are packets containing addresses known by the system to be invalid.  Logging these messages allows the SA to identify misconfigurations or attacks in progress.
custom_item_479.solution:
Configure the system to log martian packets using IPF.  Add rules logging inbound traffic containing invalid source addresses, which minimally include the system's own addresses and broadcast addresses for attached subnets.

For example, consider a system with a single network connection having IP address 192.168.1.10 with a local subnet broadcast address of 192.168.1.255.  Packets with source addresses of 192.168.1.10 and 192.168.1.255 must be logged if received by the system from the network connection.

Edit /etc/ipf/ipf.conf and add the following rules, substituting local addresses and interface names:
block in log quick on ce0 from 192.168.1.10 to any
block in log quick on ce0 from 192.168.1.255 to any

Reload the IPF rules.
Procedure:
# ipf -Fa -A -f /etc/ipf/ipf.conf

custom_item_486.info: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.
custom_item_486.solution: Migrate the system audit data path onto a separate file system.

custom_item_487.description: GEN003624 - The system must use a separate filesystem for /tmp (or equivalent).
custom_item_487.info: The use of separate filesystems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a filesystem becoming full or failing.
custom_item_487.solution: Migrate the /tmp path onto a separate file system.

custom_item_488.description: GEN003640 - The root file system must employ journaling or another mechanism ensuring file system consistency.
custom_item_488.info: File system journaling, or logging, can allow reconstruction of file system data after a system crash, thus, preserving the integrity of data that may have otherwise been lost.  Journaling file systems typically do not require consistent checks upon booting after a crash, which can improve system availability.  Some file systems employ other mechanisms to ensure consistency which also satisfy this requirement.
custom_item_488.solution: Implement file system journaling for the root file system, or use a file system using other mechanisms to ensure consistency.  If the root file system supports journaling, enable it.  If the file system does not support journaling or another mechanism to ensure consistency, a migration to a different file system will be necessary.
custom_item_488.cmd: /usr/sbin/mount -v | /usr/bin/awk '{ if ( $3 == "/" ) print $0 }' | /usr/bin/egrep -v 'ufs|jfs|vxfs|hfs|xfs|reiserfs|ext[34]|zfs' | /usr/bin/egrep -v 'logging' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no mounts found" }'

custom_item_489.description: GEN003650 - All local file systems must employ journaling or another mechanism ensuring file system consistency.
custom_item_489.info: File system journaling, or logging, can allow reconstruction of file system data after a system crash, thus preserving the integrity of data that may have otherwise been lost.  Journaling file systems typically do not require consistent checks upon booting after a crash, which can improve system availability.  Some file systems employ other mechanisms to ensure consistency which also satisfy this requirement.
custom_item_489.solution: Convert local file systems to use journaling or another mechanism ensuring file system consistency.
custom_item_489.cmd: /usr/sbin/mount -v | /usr/bin/grep '^/dev/' | /usr/bin/egrep -v '(logging|vxfs|zfs|devfs|/dev/fd)' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no mounts found" }'

custom_item_492.description: GEN003660 - The system must log authentication informational data.
custom_item_492.info: Monitoring and recording successful and unsuccessful logins assists in tracking unauthorized access to the system.
custom_item_492.solution: Edit /etc/syslog.conf and add local log destinations for auth.* or both auth.notice and auth.info.

custom_item_495.description: GEN003720 - The inetd.conf file must be owned by root or bin.
custom_item_495.info: Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_495.solution:
Change the ownership of the inetd.conf file to root or bin.

Procedure:
# chown root /etc/inet/inetd.conf

custom_item_496.description: GEN003730 - The inetd.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_496.info: Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to system groups may provide unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_496.solution:
Change the group ownership of the inetd.conf file.
Procedure:
# chgrp sys /etc/inet/inetd.conf

custom_item_497.description: GEN003740 - The inetd.conf file must have mode 0440 or less permissive.
custom_item_497.info: The Internet service daemon configuration files must be protected as malicious modification could cause Denial of Service or increase the attack surface of the system.
custom_item_497.solution:
Change the mode of the inetd.conf file.
# chmod 0440 /etc/inet/inetd.conf

custom_item_498.description: GEN003745 - The inetd.conf file must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_498.info: The Internet service daemon configuration files must be protected as malicious modification could cause Denial of Service or increase the attack surface of the system.
custom_item_498.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/inet/inetd.conf
custom_item_498.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/inet/inetd.conf | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_499.description: GEN003760 - The services file must be owned by root or bin.
custom_item_499.info: Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_499.solution:
Change the ownership of the services file to root or bin.

Procedure:
# chown root /etc/services

custom_item_500.description: GEN003770 - The services file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_500.info: Failure to give ownership of system configuration files to root or a system group provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_500.solution:
Change the group-owner of the services file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/services

custom_item_501.description: GEN003780 - The services file must have mode 0444 or less permissive.
custom_item_501.info: The services file is critical to the proper operation of network services and must be protected from unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modification could result in the failure of network services.
custom_item_501.solution:
Change the mode of the services file to 0444 or less permissive.

Procedure:
# chmod 0444 /etc/services

custom_item_502.description: GEN003790 - The services file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_502.info: The services file is critical to the proper operation of network services and must be protected from unauthorized modification.  If the services file has an extended ACL, it may be possible for unauthorized users to modify the file.  Unauthorized modification could result in the failure of network services.
custom_item_502.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/services
custom_item_502.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/services | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_503.description: GEN003800 - Inetd or xinetd logging/tracing must be enabled.
custom_item_503.info: Inetd or xinetd logging and tracing allows the system administrators to observe the IP addresses connecting to their machines and to observe what network services are being sought.  This provides valuable information when trying to find the source of malicious users and potential malicious users.
custom_item_503.solution:
Enable logging or tracing for inetd.

Procedure:
# inetadm -M tcp_trace=TRUE

Set the tcp_trace inet service property to the default for all enabled inetd-managed services.

# inetadm | grep enabled | awk '{print $NF}' | xargs -I X inetadm -m X tcp_trace=

(Note:  The trailing '=' instructs inetd to use the default value for tcp_trace.)
custom_item_503.cmd: (/usr/sbin/inetadm -p && /usr/sbin/inetadm | /usr/bin/awk '/enabled/ { print $NF }' | /usr/bin/xargs /usr/sbin/inetadm -l) | /usr/bin/grep 'tcp_trace=' | /usr/bin/grep -v '=TRUE' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no properties found" }'

custom_item_504.description: GEN003810 - The portmap or rpcbind service must not be running unless needed.
custom_item_504.info: The portmap and rpcbind services increase the attack surface of the system and should only be used when needed.  The portmap or rpcbind services are used by a variety of services using remote procedure calls (RPCs).
custom_item_504.solution:
Disable the portmap service.
# svcadm disable network/rpc/bind

custom_item_505.description: GEN003815 - The portmap or rpcbind service must not be installed unless needed.
custom_item_505.info: The portmap and rpcbind services increase the attack surface of the system and should only be used when needed.  The portmap or rpcbind services are used by a variety of services using Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs).
custom_item_505.solution:
Remove all permissions from the rpcbind file.

Procedure:
# chmod 0000 /usr/sbin/rpcbind

custom_item_506.description: GEN003820 - The rsh daemon must not be running.
custom_item_506.info:
The rshd process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service.  SSH should be used in place of this service.


Satisfies: SRG-OS-000505, SRG-OS-000555, SRG-OS-000033
custom_item_506.solution:
Disable the remote shell service and restart inetd.
Procedure:
# svcadm disable network/shell
# svcadm refresh inetd

custom_item_507.description: GEN003825 - The rshd service must not be installed.
custom_item_507.info: The rshd process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service.  SSH should be used in place of this service.
custom_item_507.solution:
Remove the SUNWrcmdr package.

Procedure:
# pkgrm SUNWrcmdr
custom_item_507.cmd: /usr/bin/pkginfo SUNWrcmdr 2>/dev/null | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "package found" }'

custom_item_508.description: GEN003830 - The rlogind service must not be running.
custom_item_508.info:
The rlogind process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service.  SSH should be used in place of this service.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000505, SRG-OS-000555, SRG-OS-000033
custom_item_508.solution:
Disable the rlogind service.

# svcadm disable rlogin
# svcadm refresh inetd

custom_item_509.description: GEN003835 - The rlogind service must not be installed.
custom_item_509.info: The rlogind process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service.  SSH should be used in place of this service.
custom_item_509.solution:
Remove the SUNWrcmdr package.

Procedure:
# pkgrm SUNWrcmdr
custom_item_509.cmd: /usr/bin/pkginfo SUNWrcmdr 2>/dev/null | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "package found" }'

custom_item_510.description: GEN003840 - The rexec daemon must not be running.
custom_item_510.info: The rexecd process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service.  SSH should be used in place of this service.
custom_item_510.solution:
# svcadm disable rexec
# svcadm refresh inetd

custom_item_511.description: GEN003845 - The rexecd service must not be installed.
custom_item_511.info: The rexecd process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service.  SSH should be used in place of this service.
custom_item_511.solution:
Remove the SUNWrcmdr package.

Procedure:
# pkgrm SUNWrcmdr
custom_item_511.cmd: /usr/bin/pkginfo SUNWrcmdr 2>/dev/null | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "package found" }'

custom_item_512.description: GEN003850 - The telnet daemon must not be running.
custom_item_512.info:
The telnet daemon provides a typically unencrypted remote access service which does not provide for the confidentiality and integrity of user passwords or the remote session.  If a privileged user were to log on using this service, the privileged user password could be compromised.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000074, SRG-OS-000520
custom_item_512.solution:
Disable the telnet daemon.

# svcadm disable telnet
# svcadm refresh inetd

custom_item_513.description: GEN003860 - The system must not have the finger service active.
custom_item_513.info: The finger service provides information about the system's users to network clients.  This information could expose information that could be used in subsequent attacks.
custom_item_513.solution:
Disable the finger service and restart inetd.
Procedure:
# svcadm disable finger
# svcadm refresh inetd

custom_item_514.description: GEN003865 - Network analysis tools must not be installed.
custom_item_514.info: Network analysis tools allow for the capture of network traffic visible to the system.
custom_item_514.solution:
Remove the network analysis tool binary from the system. The snoop binary is part of the SUNWrcmdc package, which may also be removed if none of its components are required.

Procedure:
# rm# pkgrm SUNWrcmdc
custom_item_514.cmd: /usr/bin/find / \\( -name ethereal -o -name wireshark -o -name tshark -o -name netcat -o -name tcpdump -o -name snoop \\) 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no tools found" }'

custom_item_515.description: GEN003900 - The hosts.lpd file (or equivalent) must not contain a '+' character - Listen
custom_item_515.info: Having the '+' character in the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file allows all hosts to use local system print resources.
custom_item_515.solution:
Configure IPP to use only the localhost or specified remote hosts.

Procedure:
Modify the /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf file to 'Listen' only to the local machine or a known set of hosts (i.e., Listen localhost:631).
Modify the /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf file '' element to 'Deny From All' and 'Allow from 127.0.0.1' or allowed host addresses.

Restart the IPP service:
# svcadm restart ipp-listener

custom_item_516.description: GEN003900 - The hosts.lpd file (or equivalent) must not contain a '+' character - Allow from
custom_item_516.info: Having the '+' character in the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file allows all hosts to use local system print resources.
custom_item_516.solution:
Configure IPP to use only the localhost or specified remote hosts.

Procedure:
Modify the /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf file to 'Listen' only to the local machine or a known set of hosts (i.e., Listen localhost:631).
Modify the /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf file '' element to 'Deny From All' and 'Allow from 127.0.0.1' or allowed host addresses.

Restart the IPP service:
# svcadm restart ipp-listener

custom_item_517.description: GEN003920 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file must be owned by root - /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf
custom_item_517.info: Failure to give ownership of the hosts.lpd file to root provides the designated owner, and possible unauthorized users, with the potential to modify the hosts.lpd file.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_517.solution:
Change the owner of the print service configuration files.
Procedure:

# chown root /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf /etc/printers.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf

custom_item_518.info: Failure to give ownership of the hosts.lpd file to root provides the designated owner, and possible unauthorized users, with the potential to modify the hosts.lpd file.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_518.solution:
Change the owner of the print service configuration files.
Procedure:

# chown root /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf /etc/printers.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf

custom_item_519.description: GEN003920 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file must be owned by root - SMB_CONF
custom_item_519.info: Failure to give ownership of the hosts.lpd file to root provides the designated owner, and possible unauthorized users, with the potential to modify the hosts.lpd file.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_519.solution:

Procedure:

custom_item_520.description: GEN003930 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys - /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf
custom_item_520.info: Failure to give group ownership of the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file to root, bin, sys, or system provides the members of the owning group and possible unauthorized users, with the potential to modify it.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_520.solution:
Change the group owner of the print service configuration files.
Procedure:

# chgrp bin /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf
# chgrp root /etc/printers.conf /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf

custom_item_521.description: GEN003930 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys - /etc/printers.conf
custom_item_521.info: Failure to give group ownership of the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file to root, bin, sys, or system provides the members of the owning group and possible unauthorized users, with the potential to modify it.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_521.solution:
Change the group owner of the print service configuration files.
Procedure:

# chgrp bin /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf
# chgrp root /etc/printers.conf /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf

custom_item_522.description: GEN003930 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys - SMB_CONF
custom_item_522.info: Failure to give group ownership of the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file to root, bin, sys, or system provides the members of the owning group and possible unauthorized users, with the potential to modify it.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_522.solution:
Change the group owner of the print service configuration files.
Procedure:

# chgrp bin /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf
# chgrp root /etc/printers.conf /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf

custom_item_523.description: GEN003940 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) must have mode 0644 or less permissive - httpd-standalone-ipp.conf
custom_item_523.info: Excessive permissions on the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file may permit unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_523.solution:
Change the mode of the print service configuration files to 0644 or less permissive.

Procedure:

# chmod 0644 /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf /etc/printers.conf /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf

custom_item_524.description: GEN003940 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) must have mode 0644 or less permissive - printers.conf
custom_item_524.info: Excessive permissions on the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file may permit unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_524.solution:
Change the mode of the print service configuration files to 0644 or less permissive.

Procedure:

# chmod 0644 /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf /etc/printers.conf /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf

custom_item_525.description: GEN003940 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) must have mode 0644 or less permissive - SMB_CONF
custom_item_525.info: Excessive permissions on the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file may permit unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_525.solution:
Change the mode of the print service configuration files to 0644 or less permissive.

Procedure:
