custom_item_526.description: GEN003950 - The hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_526.info: Excessive permissions on the hosts.lpd (or equivalent) file may permit unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modifications could disrupt access to local printers from authorized remote hosts or permit unauthorized remote access to local printers.
custom_item_526.solution:
Remove the extended ACLs from the files.
# chmod A- /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf /etc/printers.conf /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf
custom_item_526.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/apache/httpd-standalone-ipp.conf /etc/printers.conf @SMB_CONF@ | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_527.description: GEN003960 - The traceroute command owner must be root.
custom_item_527.info: If the traceroute command owner has not been set to root, an unauthorized user could use this command to obtain knowledge of the network topology inside the firewall.  This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information possibly leading to system and network compromise.
custom_item_527.solution:
Change the owner of the traceroute command to root.
Example procedure:
# chown root /usr/sbin/traceroute

custom_item_528.description: GEN003980 - The traceroute command must be group-owned by sys, bin, or root.
custom_item_528.info: If the group owner of the traceroute command has not been set to a system group, unauthorized users could have access to the command and use it to gain information regarding a network's topology inside of the firewall.  This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information possibly leading to system and network compromise.
custom_item_528.solution:
Change the group-owner of the traceroute command to root.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /usr/sbin/traceroute

custom_item_529.description: GEN004000 - The traceroute file must have mode 0700 or less permissive.
custom_item_529.info: If the mode of the traceroute executable is more permissive than 0700, malicious code could be inserted by an attacker and triggered whenever the traceroute command is executed by authorized users.  Additionally, if an unauthorized user is granted executable permissions to the traceroute command, it could be used to gain information about the network topology behind the firewall.  This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information that may lead to system and network compromise.
custom_item_529.solution:
Change the mode of the traceroute command.
# chmod 0700 /usr/sbin/traceroute

custom_item_530.description: GEN004010 - The traceroute file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_530.info: If an extended ACL exists on the traceroute executable file, it may provide unauthorized users with access to the file.  Malicious code could be inserted by an attacker and triggered whenever the traceroute command is executed by authorized users.  Additionally, if an unauthorized user is granted executable permissions to the traceroute command, it could be used to gain information about the network topology behind the firewall.  This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information possibly leading to system and network compromise.
custom_item_530.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /usr/sbin/traceroute
custom_item_530.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /usr/sbin/traceroute | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_534.description: GEN004360 - The alias file must be owned by root.
custom_item_534.info: If the alias file is not owned by root, an unauthorized user may modify the file to add aliases to run malicious code or redirect email.
custom_item_534.solution:
Change the owner of the /etc/mail/aliases file (or equivalent, such as /usr/lib/aliases) to root.

Procedure:
# chown root /etc/mail/aliases

custom_item_535.description: GEN004370 - The aliases file must be group-owned by root, sys, smmsp, or bin.
custom_item_535.info: If the alias file is not group-owned by root or a system group, an unauthorized user may modify the file to add aliases to run malicious code or redirect email.
custom_item_535.solution:
Change the group owner of the /etc/mail/aliases files.

Procedure:
# chgrp bin /etc/mail/aliases
# chgrp smmsp /etc/mail/aliases.db

custom_item_536.description: GEN004380 - The alias file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_536.info: Excessive permissions on the aliases file may permit unauthorized modification.  If the alias file is modified by an unauthorized user, they may modify the file to run malicious code or redirect email.
custom_item_536.solution:
Change the mode of the /etc/mail/aliases files (or equivalent, such as /usr/lib/aliases) to 0644.

    Procedure:
    # chmod 0644 /etc/mail/aliases /etc/mail/aliases.db

custom_item_537.description: GEN004390 - The alias file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_537.info: Excessive permissions on the aliases file may permit unauthorized modification.  If the alias file is modified by an unauthorized user, they may modify the file to run malicious code or redirect email.
custom_item_537.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the files.
# chmod A- /etc/mail/aliases /etc/mail/aliases.db
custom_item_537.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/mail/aliases* | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_538.description: GEN004440 - Sendmail logging must not be set to less than nine in the sendmail.cf file.
custom_item_538.info: If Sendmail is not configured to log at level 9, system logs may not contain the information necessary for tracking unauthorized use of the Sendmail service.
custom_item_538.solution: Edit the sendmail.conf file, locate the 'O L' or LogLevel entry and change it to 9.

custom_item_539.description: GEN004410 - Files executed through a mail aliases file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys, and must reside within a directory group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_539.info:
If a file executed through a mail aliases file is not group-owned by root or a system group, it may be subject to unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modification of files executed through aliases may allow unauthorized users to attain root privileges.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_539.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file referenced from /etc/mail/aliases.

Procedure:
# chgrp root
custom_item_539.cmd: egrep -v '^(#|$)' /etc/mail/aliases | grep '|' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no aliases found" }'

custom_item_540.description: GEN004430 - Files executed through a mail aliases file must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_540.info:
Excessive permissions on files executed through a mail alias file could result in modification by an unauthorized user, execution of malicious code, and/or system compromise.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_540.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- [file referenced from aliases]
custom_item_540.cmd: egrep -v '^(#|$)' /etc/mail/aliases | grep '|' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no aliases found" }'

custom_item_541.description: GEN004460 - The system syslog service must log informational and more severe SMTP service messages.
custom_item_541.info: If informational and more severe SMTP service messages are not logged, malicious activity on the system may go unnoticed.
custom_item_541.solution: Edit the syslog.conf file and add a configuration line specifying an appropriate destination for mail.crit syslogs.

custom_item_542.description: GEN004480 - The SMTP service log file must be owned by root - /var/adm/messages
custom_item_542.info: If the SMTP service log file is not owned by root, then unauthorized personnel may modify or delete the file to hide a system compromise.
custom_item_542.solution:
Change the ownership of the Sendmail log file.
# chown root

custom_item_543.description: GEN004480 - The SMTP service log file must be owned by root - /var/log/syslog
custom_item_543.info: If the SMTP service log file is not owned by root, then unauthorized personnel may modify or delete the file to hide a system compromise.
custom_item_543.solution:
Change the ownership of the Sendmail log file.
# chown root

custom_item_544.description: GEN004480 - The SMTP service log file must be owned by root - MAIL_LOG
custom_item_544.info: If the SMTP service log file is not owned by root, then unauthorized personnel may modify or delete the file to hide a system compromise.
custom_item_544.solution:
Change the ownership of the Sendmail log file.
# chown root

custom_item_545.description: GEN004500 - The SMTP service log file must have mode 0644 or less permissive - /var/log/syslog
custom_item_545.info: If the SMTP service log file is more permissive than 0644, unauthorized users may be allowed to change the log file.
custom_item_545.solution:
Change the mode of the SMTP service log file.

Procedure:
# chmod 0644

custom_item_546.description: GEN004500 - The SMTP service log file must have mode 0644 or less permissive - /var/adm/messages
custom_item_546.info: If the SMTP service log file is more permissive than 0644, unauthorized users may be allowed to change the log file.
custom_item_546.solution:
Change the mode of the SMTP service log file.

Procedure:
# chmod 0644

custom_item_547.description: GEN004500 - The SMTP service log file must have mode 0644 or less permissive - MAIL_LOG
custom_item_547.info: If the SMTP service log file is more permissive than 0644, unauthorized users may be allowed to change the log file.
custom_item_547.solution:
Change the mode of the SMTP service log file.

Procedure:
# chmod 0644

custom_item_548.description: GEN004510 - The SMTP service log file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_548.info: If the SMTP service log file has an extended ACL, unauthorized users may be allowed to access or to modify the log file.
custom_item_548.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- [log file]
custom_item_548.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /var/adm/messages /var/adm/maillog @MAIL_LOG@ | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_551.description: GEN004560 - The SMTP services SMTP greeting must not provide version information.
custom_item_551.info: The version of the SMTP service can be used by attackers to plan an attack based on vulnerabilities present in the specific version.
custom_item_551.solution:
Ensure Sendmail or its equivalent has been configured to mask the version information. If necessary, change the O SmtpGreetingMessage line in the /etc/mail/sendmail.cf file as noted below.
O SmtpGreetingMessage=$j Sendmail $v/$Z; $b
Change it to:
O SmtpGreetingMessage= Mail Server Ready ; $b

custom_item_552.description: GEN004580 - The system must not use .forward files.
custom_item_552.info: The .forward file allows users to automatically forward mail to another system. Use of .forward files could allow the unauthorized forwarding of mail and could potentially create mail loops which could degrade system performance.
custom_item_552.solution:
Remove .forward files from the system.

# rm .forward

Update the sendmail.cf file to ignore .forward files by adding
ForwardPath=''.

custom_item_553.description: GEN004600 - The SMTP service must be an up-to-date version.
custom_item_553.info: The SMTP service version on the system must be current to avoid exposing vulnerabilities present in unpatched versions.
custom_item_553.solution: Obtain and install the latest version of Sendmail from Oracle through normal software update processes, as implemented locally.

custom_item_554.description: GEN004620 - The Sendmail server must have the debug feature disabled.
custom_item_554.info: Debug mode is a feature present in older versions of Sendmail which, if not disabled, may allow an attacker to gain access to a system through the Sendmail service.
custom_item_554.solution: Obtain and install a more recent version of Sendmail, which does not implement the DEBUG feature.

custom_item_555.description: GEN004640 - The SMTP service must not have a uudecode alias active.
custom_item_555.info: A common configuration for older Mail Transfer Agents (MTAs) includes an alias for the decode user. All mail sent to this user is sent to the uudecode program, which automatically converts and stores files. By sending mail to decode or uudecode aliases present on some systems, a remote attacker may be able to create or overwrite files on the remote host. This could possibly be used to gain remote access.
custom_item_555.solution:
Comment out active decode and uudecode aliases in the aliases file.

# vi /usr/mail/aliases

Activate updated aliases file.

# newaliases

custom_item_556.description: GEN004660 - The SMTP service must not have the EXPN feature active.
custom_item_556.info:
The SMTP EXPN function allows an attacker to determine if an account exists on a system, providing significant assistance to a brute-force attack on user accounts. EXPN may also provide additional information concerning users on the system, such as the full names of account owners.

False Positives:
False positives may occur with the SMTP EXPN check. According to RFC821, it is acceptable for a server to respond with a 250 (success) or 550 (failure) when the server supports the EXPN command. For example, some servers return '550 EXPN command not available', meaning the command is not supported and the machine is not vulnerable. However, a result of '550 That is a mailing list, not a user' would be a failure code, but not an indication of an error, and the machine would be vulnerable. If false positive is suspected, check the log file for the response from the server.
custom_item_556.solution:
Edit the sendmail.cf file and add Opnoexpn option.
Restart the Sendmail service.

custom_item_557.description: GEN004680 - The SMTP service must not have the VRFY feature active.
custom_item_557.info: The VRFY (Verify) command allows an attacker to determine if an account exists on a system, providing significant assistance to a brute-force attack on user accounts. VRFY may provide additional information about users on the system, such as the full names of account owners.
custom_item_557.solution: If Sendmail is running, add the line Opnovrfy to the Sendmail configuration file, usually located in /etc/sendmail.cf. For other mail servers, contact the vendor for information on how to disable the verify command. Newer versions of Sendmail are available at http://www.sendmail.org or from ftp://ftp.cs.berkeley.edu/ucb/sendmail.

custom_item_559.description: GEN004700 - The Sendmail service must not have the wizard backdoor active.
custom_item_559.info: Very old installations of the Sendmail mailing system contained a feature whereby a remote user connecting to the SMTP port can enter the WIZ command and be given an interactive shell with root privileges.
custom_item_559.solution:
If the WIZ command is enabled on Sendmail, it should be disabled by adding this line to the sendmail.cf configuration file (it must be typed in uppercase).

OW*

For the change to take effect, kill the Sendmail process, refreeze the sendmail.cf file, and restart the Sendmail process.

custom_item_562.description: GEN004710 - Mail relaying must be restricted - promiscuous_relay'
custom_item_562.info: If unrestricted mail relaying is permitted, unauthorized senders could use this host as a mail relay for the purpose of sending SPAM or other unauthorized activity.
custom_item_562.solution:
If the system uses Sendmail, edit the sendmail.mc file and remove the promiscuous_relay configuration. Rebuild the sendmail.cf file from the modified sendmail.mc and restart the service. If the system does not need to receive mail from external hosts, add one or more DaemonPortOptions lines referencing system loopback addresses (such as 'O DaemonPortOptions=Addr=127.0.0.1,Port=smtp,Name=MTA') and remove lines containing non-loopback addresses. Restart the service.

If the system uses Postfix, edit the main.cf file and add or edit the smtpd_client_restrictions line to have contents permit mynetworks, reject or a similarly restrictive rule. If the system does not need to receive mail from external hosts, add or edit the inet_interfaces line to have contents loopback-only or a set of loopback addresses for the system. Restart the service.

If the system is using other SMTP software, consult the software's documentation for procedures to restrict mail relaying.

custom_item_565.description: GEN004710 - Mail relaying must be restricted - Postfix relay reject
custom_item_565.info: If unrestricted mail relaying is permitted, unauthorized senders could use this host as a mail relay for the purpose of sending SPAM or other unauthorized activity.
custom_item_565.solution:
If the system uses Sendmail, edit the sendmail.mc file and remove the promiscuous_relay configuration. Rebuild the sendmail.cf file from the modified sendmail.mc and restart the service. If the system does not need to receive mail from external hosts, add one or more DaemonPortOptions lines referencing system loopback addresses (such as 'O DaemonPortOptions=Addr=127.0.0.1,Port=smtp,Name=MTA') and remove lines containing non-loopback addresses. Restart the service.

If the system uses Postfix, edit the main.cf file and add or edit the smtpd_client_restrictions line to have contents permit mynetworks, reject or a similarly restrictive rule. If the system does not need to receive mail from external hosts, add or edit the inet_interfaces line to have contents loopback-only or a set of loopback addresses for the system. Restart the service.

If the system is using other SMTP software, consult the software's documentation for procedures to restrict mail relaying.

custom_item_566.description: GEN004710 - Mail relaying must be restricted - Postfix relay not permit
custom_item_566.info: If unrestricted mail relaying is permitted, unauthorized senders could use this host as a mail relay for the purpose of sending SPAM or other unauthorized activity.
custom_item_566.solution:
If the system uses Sendmail, edit the sendmail.mc file and remove the promiscuous_relay configuration. Rebuild the sendmail.cf file from the modified sendmail.mc and restart the service. If the system does not need to receive mail from external hosts, add one or more DaemonPortOptions lines referencing system loopback addresses (such as 'O DaemonPortOptions=Addr=127.0.0.1,Port=smtp,Name=MTA') and remove lines containing non-loopback addresses. Restart the service.

If the system uses Postfix, edit the main.cf file and add or edit the smtpd_client_restrictions line to have contents permit mynetworks, reject or a similarly restrictive rule. If the system does not need to receive mail from external hosts, add or edit the inet_interfaces line to have contents loopback-only or a set of loopback addresses for the system. Restart the service.

If the system is using other SMTP software, consult the software's documentation for procedures to restrict mail relaying.

custom_item_567.description: GEN004800 - Unencrypted FTP must not be used on the system.
custom_item_567.info: FTP is typically unencrypted and, therefore, presents confidentiality and integrity risks.  FTP may be protected by encryption in certain cases, such as when used in a Kerberos environment.   SFTP and FTPS are encrypted alternatives to FTP.

custom_item_568.description: GEN004820 - Anonymous FTP must not be active on the system unless authorized.
custom_item_568.info: Due to the numerous vulnerabilities inherent in anonymous FTP, it is recommended that it not be used. If anonymous FTP must be used on a system, the requirement must be authorized and approved in the system accreditation package.
custom_item_568.solution: Configure the FTP service to not permit anonymous logins.

custom_item_569.description: GEN004880 - The ftpusers file must exist.
custom_item_569.info: The ftpusers file contains a list of accounts not allowed to use FTP to transfer files. If this file does not exist, then unauthorized accounts can utilize FTP.
custom_item_569.solution: Create a /etc/ftpd/ftpusers file containing a list of accounts not authorized for FTP.

custom_item_570.description: GEN004900 - The ftpusers file must contain account names not allowed to use FTP.
custom_item_570.info: The ftpusers file contains a list of accounts that are not allowed to use FTP to transfer files. If the file does not contain the names of all accounts not authorized to use FTP, then unauthorized use of FTP may take place.
custom_item_570.solution: Add accounts not allowed to use FTP to the /etc/ftpd/ftpusers file.
custom_item_570.cmd: /usr/bin/logins -sto | /usr/bin/cut -f1 -d: | /usr/bin/egrep -v -f /etc/ftpd/ftpusers /dev/stdin 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no accounts found" }'

custom_item_571.description: GEN004920 - The ftpusers file must be owned by root.
custom_item_571.info: If the file ftpusers is not owned by root, an unauthorized user may modify the file to allow unauthorized accounts to use FTP.
custom_item_571.solution:
Change the owner of the ftpusers file to root.
# chown root /etc/ftpd/ftpusers

custom_item_572.description: GEN004930 - The ftpusers file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_572.info: If the ftpusers file is not group-owned by root or a system group, an unauthorized user may modify the file to allow unauthorized accounts to use FTP.
custom_item_572.solution:
Change the group owner of the ftpusers file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/ftpusers

custom_item_573.description: GEN004940 - The ftpusers file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_573.info: Excessive permissions on the ftpusers file could permit unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modification could result in Denial of Service to authorized FTP users or permit unauthorized users to access the FTP service.
custom_item_573.solution:
Change the mode of the ftpusers file to 0640.
# chmod 0640 /etc/ftpd/ftpusers

custom_item_574.description: GEN004950 - The ftpusers file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_574.info: Excessive permissions on the ftpusers file could permit unauthorized modification.  Unauthorized modification could result in Denial of Service to authorized FTP users or permit unauthorized users to access the FTP service.
custom_item_574.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/ftpd/ftpusers
custom_item_574.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/ftpd/ftpusers | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_575.description: GEN004980 - The FTP daemon must be configured for logging or verbose mode.
custom_item_575.info: The -l option allows basic logging of connections.  The verbose (on HP) and the debug (on Solaris) allow logging of what files the FTP session transferred.  This extra logging makes it possible to easily track which files are being transferred onto or from a system.  If they are not configured, the only option for tracking is the audit files.  The audit files are much harder to read.  If auditing is not properly configured, then there would be no record at all of the file transfer transactions.
custom_item_575.solution:
Add the -l option to the exec name-value pair used by SMF to invoke the FTP daemon.
# inetadm -m ftp exec='/usr/sbin/in.ftpd [other options] -l'
Refresh inetd.
# svcadm refresh inetd

custom_item_576.description: GEN005000 - Anonymous FTP accounts must not have a functional shell.
custom_item_576.info: If an anonymous FTP account has been configured to use a functional shell, attackers could gain access to the shell if the account is compromised.
custom_item_576.solution: Configure anonymous FTP accounts to use a non-functional shell. If necessary, edit the /etc/passwd file to remove any functioning shells associated with the FTP account and replace them with non-functioning shells, such as, /dev/null.

custom_item_577.description: GEN005040 - All FTP users must have a default umask of 077.
custom_item_577.info: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files.  An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive.  Although umask is stored as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0.
custom_item_577.solution: Edit the initialization files for the FTP user and set the umask to 077.

custom_item_578.description: GEN005080 - The TFTP daemon must operate in secure mode which provides access only to a single directory on the host file system.
custom_item_578.info: Secure mode limits TFTP requests to a specific directory.  If TFTP is not running in secure mode, it may be able to write to any file or directory and may seriously impair system integrity, confidentiality, and availability.
custom_item_578.solution:
Edit /etc/inet/inetd.conf and add the -s parameter to TFTPD.
# inetconv

OR

Update the SMF entry for the TFTP daemon.
# svccfg -s tftp/udp6 setprop inetd_start/exec = 'astring:\'/usr/sbin/in.tftpd -s\''

custom_item_579.description: GEN005100 - The TFTP daemon must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
custom_item_579.info: If TFTP runs with the setuid or setgid bit set, it may be able to write to any file or directory and may seriously impair system integrity, confidentiality, and availability.
custom_item_579.solution:
Change the mode of the TFTP daemon.

Procedure:
# chmod 0755 /usr/sbin/in.tftpd

custom_item_581.description: GEN005120 - The TFTP daemon must be configured to vendor specifications, including a dedicated TFTP user account, a non-login shell, such as /bin/false, and a home directory owned by the TFTP user - dedicated TFTP account
custom_item_581.info: If TFTP has a valid shell, it increases the likelihood of someone logging to the TFTP account and compromising the system.
custom_item_581.solution:
Create a TFTP user account if none exists.
Assign a non-login shell to the TFTP user account, such as /bin/false.
Assign a home directory to the TFTP user account.

custom_item_582.description: GEN005120 - The TFTP daemon must be configured to vendor specifications, including a dedicated TFTP user account, a non-login shell, such as /bin/false, and a home directory owned by the TFTP user - a non-login shell
custom_item_582.info: If TFTP has a valid shell, it increases the likelihood of someone logging to the TFTP account and compromising the system.
custom_item_582.solution:
Create a TFTP user account if none exists.
Assign a non-login shell to the TFTP user account, such as /bin/false.
Assign a home directory to the TFTP user account.

custom_item_583.description: GEN005120 - The TFTP daemon must be configured to vendor specifications, including a dedicated TFTP user account, a non-login shell, such as /bin/false, and a home directory owned by the TFTP user - home directory
custom_item_583.info: If TFTP has a valid shell, it increases the likelihood of someone logging to the TFTP account and compromising the system.
custom_item_583.solution:
Create a TFTP user account if none exists.
Assign a non-login shell to the TFTP user account, such as /bin/false.
Assign a home directory to the TFTP user account.

custom_item_584.description: GEN005140 - Any active TFTP daemon must be authorized and approved in the system accreditation package.
custom_item_584.info: TFTP is a file transfer protocol often used by embedded systems to obtain configuration data or software.    The service is unencrypted and does not require authentication of requests.  Data available using this service may be subject to unauthorized access or interception.
custom_item_584.solution:
Disable the TFTP daemon.
# svcadm disable svc:/network/tftp/*
# svcadm refresh inetd
If TFTP is found enabled, it is a finding if it is not documented.

custom_item_585.description: GEN005160 - Any X Windows host must write .Xauthority files.
custom_item_585.info:
.Xauthority files ensure the user is authorized to access the specific X Windows host.  If .Xauthority files are not used, it may be possible to obtain unauthorized access to the X Windows host.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_585.solution: Ensure the X Windows host is configured to write .Xauthority files into user home directories. Edit the Xaccess file. Ensure the line that writes the .Xauthority file is uncommented.
custom_item_585.cmd: /usr/bin/logins -uto | /usr/bin/cut -f1 -d: | /usr/bin/xargs -n1 -IUSER ls USER/.Xauthority 2>&1 | /usr/bin/egrep -v '(nobody|nobody4|noaccess|ftp)' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no files found" }'

custom_item_586.description: GEN005180 - All .Xauthority files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_586.info: .Xauthority files ensure the user is authorized to access the specific X Windows host.  Excessive permissions may permit unauthorized modification of these files, which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized access or allow unauthorized access to be obtained.
custom_item_586.solution:
Change the mode of the .Xauthority files.

Procedure:
# chmod 0600 .Xauthority

custom_item_587.description: GEN005190 - The .Xauthority files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_587.info: .Xauthority files ensure the user is authorized to access the specific X Windows host.  Extended ACLs may permit unauthorized modification of these files, which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized access or allow unauthorized access to be obtained.
custom_item_587.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- .Xauthority
custom_item_587.cmd: /usr/bin/awk -F: '$3 > 99 { print $6 }' /etc/passwd | /usr/bin/sort -u | /usr/bin/xargs -n1 -IDIR /usr/bin/ls -lLd DIR/.Xauthority | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_588.description: GEN005201 - X11 forwarding for SSH must be disabled.
custom_item_588.info: Enabling X11 Forwarding on the host can permit a malicious user to secretly open another X11 connection to another remote client during the session and perform unobtrusive activities such as keystroke monitoring. If the X11 services are not required for the system's intended function, they should be disabled or restricted as appropriate to the user's needs.
custom_item_588.solution:
The root role is required.

Modify the sshd_config file.

# vi /etc/ssh/sshd_config

Locate the line containing:

X11Forwarding

Change it to:

X11Forwarding no

Restart the SSH service.

# svcadm restart svc:/network/ssh

custom_item_589.description: GEN005202 - The sshd server must bind the X11 forwarding server to the loopback address.
custom_item_589.info:
Enabling X11 Forwarding on the host can permit a malicious user to secretly open another X11 connection to another remote client during the session and perform unobtrusive activities such as keystroke monitoring. If the X11 services are not required for the system's intended function, they should be disabled or restricted as appropriate to the user's needs.
By default, sshd binds the forwarding server to the loopback address and sets the hostname part of the DISPLAY environment variable to 'localhost'. This prevents remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display.
custom_item_589.solution:
The root role is required.

Modify the sshd_config file.

# vi /etc/ssh/sshd_config

Locate the line containing:

X11UseLocalhost

Change it to:

X11UseLocalhost yes

Restart the SSH service.

# svcadm restart svc:/network/ssh

custom_item_590.description: GEN005260 - X Window System connections that are not required must be disabled.
custom_item_590.info: If unauthorized clients are permitted access to the X server, a user's X session may be compromised.
custom_item_590.solution: Disable the X Windows server on the system.
custom_item_590.cmd: /usr/bin/ps -ef | /usr/bin/egrep 'X(11|org)' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no processes found" }'

custom_item_591.description: GEN005280 - The system must not have the UUCP service active.
custom_item_591.info: The UUCP utility is designed to assist in transferring files, executing remote commands, and sending email between UNIX systems over phone lines and direct connections between systems. The UUCP utility is a primitive and arcane system with many security issues. There are alternate data transfer utilities/products that can be configured to more securely transfer data by providing for authentication,  as well as encryption.
custom_item_591.solution:
# svcadm disable uucp
# svcadm refresh inetd

custom_item_592.description: GEN005300 - SNMP communities, users, and passphrases must be changed from the default - /etc/sma/snmp/snmpd.conf
custom_item_592.info: Whether active or not, default SNMP passwords, users, and passphrases must be changed to maintain security. If the service is running with the default authenticators, then anyone can gather data about the system and the network and use the information to potentially compromise the integrity of the system or network(s).
custom_item_592.solution: Change the default passwords. To change them, locate the snmpd.conf file and edit it. Locate the line system-group-read-community which has a default password of public and make the password something more random (less guessable). Make the same changes for the lines that read system-group-write-community, read-community, write-community, trap, and trap-community. Read the information in the file carefully. The trap is defining who to send traps to, for instance, by default. It is not a password, but the name of a host.

custom_item_593.description: GEN005300 - SNMP communities, users, and passphrases must be changed from the default - /var/sma_snmp/snmpd.conf
custom_item_593.info: Whether active or not, default SNMP passwords, users, and passphrases must be changed to maintain security. If the service is running with the default authenticators, then anyone can gather data about the system and the network and use the information to potentially compromise the integrity of the system or network(s).
custom_item_593.solution: Change the default passwords. To change them, locate the snmpd.conf file and edit it. Locate the line system-group-read-community which has a default password of public and make the password something more random (less guessable). Make the same changes for the lines that read system-group-write-community, read-community, write-community, trap, and trap-community. Read the information in the file carefully. The trap is defining who to send traps to, for instance, by default. It is not a password, but the name of a host.

custom_item_594.description: GEN005300 - SNMP communities, users, and passphrases must be changed from the default - /etc/snmp/conf/snmpd.conf
custom_item_594.info: Whether active or not, default SNMP passwords, users, and passphrases must be changed to maintain security. If the service is running with the default authenticators, then anyone can gather data about the system and the network and use the information to potentially compromise the integrity of the system or network(s).
custom_item_594.solution: Change the default passwords. To change them, locate the snmpd.conf file and edit it. Locate the line system-group-read-community which has a default password of public and make the password something more random (less guessable). Make the same changes for the lines that read system-group-write-community, read-community, write-community, trap, and trap-community. Read the information in the file carefully. The trap is defining who to send traps to, for instance, by default. It is not a password, but the name of a host.

custom_item_595.description: GEN005300 - SNMP communities, users, and passphrases must be changed from the default - /usr/sfw/lib/sma_snmp/snmpd.conf
custom_item_595.info: Whether active or not, default SNMP passwords, users, and passphrases must be changed to maintain security. If the service is running with the default authenticators, then anyone can gather data about the system and the network and use the information to potentially compromise the integrity of the system or network(s).
custom_item_595.solution: Change the default passwords. To change them, locate the snmpd.conf file and edit it. Locate the line system-group-read-community which has a default password of public and make the password something more random (less guessable). Make the same changes for the lines that read system-group-write-community, read-community, write-community, trap, and trap-community. Read the information in the file carefully. The trap is defining who to send traps to, for instance, by default. It is not a password, but the name of a host.

custom_item_596.description: GEN005305 - The SNMP service must use only SNMPv3 or its successors - /etc/sma/snmp/snmpd.conf
custom_item_596.info: SNMP Versions 1 and 2 are not considered secure. Without the strong authentication and privacy  provided by the SNMP Version 3 User-based Security Model (USM), an attacker or other unauthorized users may gain access to detailed system management information and use the information to launch attacks against the system.
custom_item_596.solution:
Edit non-compliant snmpd.conf files and remove references to the v1, v2c, community, or com2sec.  Restart the SNMP service.
# svcadm restart svc:/application/management/sma:default

custom_item_597.description: GEN005305 - The SNMP service must use only SNMPv3 or its successors - /var/sma_snmp/snmpd.conf
custom_item_597.info: SNMP Versions 1 and 2 are not considered secure. Without the strong authentication and privacy  provided by the SNMP Version 3 User-based Security Model (USM), an attacker or other unauthorized users may gain access to detailed system management information and use the information to launch attacks against the system.
custom_item_597.solution:
Edit non-compliant snmpd.conf files and remove references to the v1, v2c, community, or com2sec.  Restart the SNMP service.
# svcadm restart svc:/application/management/sma:default

custom_item_600.info: The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.
custom_item_600.solution:
Change the mode of the SNMP daemon configuration file to 0600.

Procedure:

custom_item_604.description: GEN005340 - Management Information Base (MIB) files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_604.info: The ability to read the MIB file could impart special knowledge to an intruder or malicious user about the ability to extract compromising information about the system or network.
custom_item_604.solution:
Change the mode of MIB files to 0640.

Procedure:
# chmod 0640
custom_item_604.cmd: /usr/bin/find /etc/sma/snmp/ /etc/snmp/conf/ /var/sma_snmp/ /usr/sfw/lib/sma_snmp/ -type f | /usr/bin/grep -i mib | /usr/bin/egrep -v '\.conf$' | /usr/bin/xargs /usr/bin/ls -lL | /usr/bin/egrep -v '^.[r-][w-]-[r-]----- ' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no files found" }'

custom_item_605.description: GEN005350 - Management Information Base (MIB) files must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_605.info: The ability to read the MIB file could impart special knowledge to an intruder or malicious user about the ability to extract compromising information about the system or network.
custom_item_605.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- [mib file]
custom_item_605.cmd: /usr/bin/find /etc/sma/snmp/ /etc/snmp/conf/ /var/sma_snmp/ /usr/sfw/lib/sma_snmp/ -type f -exec /usr/bin/ls -lLd {} \\; | /usr/bin/grep -i mib | /usr/bin/egrep -v '\.conf$' | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_606.description: GEN005360 - The snmpd.conf files must be owned by root - /etc/sma/snmp/snmpd.conf
custom_item_606.info: The snmpd.conf files contain authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.  If the files are not owned by root, they may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.
custom_item_606.solution:
Change the owner of the snmpd.conf file to root.

Procedure:
# chown root

custom_item_607.info: The snmpd.conf files contain authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.  If the files are not owned by root, they may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.
custom_item_607.solution:

Procedure:

custom_item_608.info: The snmpd.conf files contain authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.  If the files are not owned by root, they may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.

custom_item_609.info: The snmpd.conf files contain authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.  If the files are not owned by root, they may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.

custom_item_610.description: GEN005365 - The snmpd.conf file must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin - /etc/sma/snmp/snmpd.conf
custom_item_610.info: The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.  If the file is not group-owned by a system group, it may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.
custom_item_610.solution:
Change the group ownership of the SNMP configuration file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/sma/snmp/snmpd.conf /var/sma_snmp/snmpd.conf /etc/snmp/conf/snmpd.conf /usr/sfw/lib/sma_snmp/snmpd.conf

custom_item_612.info: The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.  If the file is not group-owned by a system group, it may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.
