custom_item_615.description: GEN005390 - The /etc/syslog.conf file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
custom_item_615.info: Unauthorized users must not be allowed to access or modify the /etc/syslog.conf file.
custom_item_615.solution:
Change the permissions of the syslog configuration file.
# chmod 0640 /etc/syslog.conf

custom_item_616.description: GEN005395 - The /etc/syslog.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_616.info: Unauthorized users must not be allowed to access or modify the /etc/syslog.conf file.
custom_item_616.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/syslog.conf
custom_item_616.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/syslog.conf | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_617.description: GEN005400 - The /etc/syslog.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_617.info: If the /etc/syslog.conf file is not owned by root, unauthorized users could be allowed to view, edit, or delete important system messages handled by the syslog facility.
custom_item_617.solution:
Use the chown command to set the owner to root.
# chown root /etc/syslog.conf

custom_item_618.description: GEN005420 - The /etc/syslog.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_618.info: If the group owner of /etc/syslog.conf is not root, bin, or sys, unauthorized users could be permitted to view, edit, or delete important system messages handled by the syslog facility.
custom_item_618.solution:
Change the group owner of the /etc/syslog.conf file to root, bin, or sys.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/syslog.conf

custom_item_619.description: GEN005450 - The system must use a remote syslog server (log host).
custom_item_619.info: A syslog server (log host) receives syslog messages from one or more systems.  This data can be used as an authoritative log source in the event a system is compromised and its local logs are suspect.
custom_item_619.solution: Edit the syslog configuration file and add an appropriate remote syslog server.

custom_item_620.description: GEN005460 - The system must only use remote syslog servers (log hosts) justified and documented using site-defined procedures.
custom_item_620.info:
If a remote log host is in use and it has not been justified and documented with the IAO, sensitive information could be obtained by unauthorized users without the SA's knowledge.  A remote log host is any host to which the system is sending syslog messages over a network.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_620.solution: Remove, replace, or document the referenced undocumented log host.

custom_item_621.description: GEN005480 - The syslog daemon must not accept remote messages unless it is a syslog server documented using site-defined procedures.
custom_item_621.info: Unintentionally running a syslog server accepting remote messages puts the system at increased risk.  Malicious syslog messages sent to the server could exploit vulnerabilities in the server software itself, could introduce misleading information in to the system's logs, or could fill the system's storage leading to a Denial of Service.
custom_item_621.solution:
# svccfg -s system-log setprop config/log_from_remote=false
# svcadm refresh system-log

custom_item_622.description: GEN005500 - The SSH daemon must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.
custom_item_622.info: SSHv1 is not a DoD-approved protocol and has many well-known vulnerability exploits.  Exploits of the SSH daemon could provide immediate root access to the system.
custom_item_622.solution:
Edit the configuration file and modify the Protocol line to look like:

Protocol 2

Reload sshd:
kill -HUP

custom_item_623.description: GEN005501 - The SSH client must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.
custom_item_623.info: SSHv1 is not a DoD-approved protocol and has many well-known vulnerability exploits.  Exploits of the SSH client could provide access to the system with the privileges of the user running the client.
custom_item_623.solution: Edit the /etc/ssh/ssh_config file and add or edit a Protocol configuration line that does not allow versions less than 2.

custom_item_624.description: GEN005504 - The SSH daemon must only listen on management network addresses unless authorized for uses other than management.
custom_item_624.info: The SSH daemon should only listen on network addresses designated for management traffic.  If the system has multiple network interfaces and SSH listens on addresses not designated for management traffic, the SSH service could be subject to unauthorized access.  If SSH is used for purposes other than management, such as providing an SFTP service, the list of approved listening addresses may be documented.
custom_item_624.solution: Edit the SSH daemon configuration to specify listening network addresses designated for management traffic.

custom_item_625.description: GEN005505 - The operating system must implement DoD-approved encryption to protect the confidentiality of SSH connections.
custom_item_625.info:
DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.  SSHv2 ciphers meeting this requirement are 3DES and AES.

By specifying a cipher list with the order of ciphers being in a 'strongest to weakest' orientation, the system will automatically attempt to use the strongest cipher for securing SSH connections.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000033, SRG-OS-000505, SRG-OS-000555
custom_item_625.solution:
Edit /etc/ssh/sshd_config and change or set the Ciphers line to the following.

Ciphers aes256-ctr, aes192-ctr, aes128-ctr

custom_item_626.description: GEN005506 - The SSH daemon must be configured to not use Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) ciphers.
custom_item_626.info: The Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen plain text attacks and must not be used.
custom_item_626.solution:
Edit /etc/ssh/sshd_config and add or edit the 'Ciphers' line. Only include ciphers that start with '3des' or 'aes' and do not contain 'cbc'. For the list of available ciphers for the particular version of your software, consult the sshd_config manpage.

Restart the SSH daemon.

custom_item_627.description: GEN005507 - The SSH daemon must be configured to only use Message Authentication Codes (MACs) employing FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash algorithms.
custom_item_627.info:
DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash functions.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000250, SRG-OS-000495, SRG-OS-000500
custom_item_627.solution: Edit the SSH daemon configuration and remove any MACs that are not hmac-sha1 or a better hmac algorithm that is on the FIPS 140-2 approved list. If necessary, add a MACs line.

custom_item_628.description: GEN005510 - The SSH client must be configured to only use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.
custom_item_628.info:
DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.  SSHv2 ciphers meeting this requirement are 3DES and AES.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000033, SRG-OS-000505, SRG-OS-000555
custom_item_628.solution: Edit /etc/ssh/ssh_config and add or edit the 'Ciphers' line.  Only include ciphers that start with '3des' or 'aes' and do not contain 'cbc'.  For the list of available ciphers for the particular version of your software, consult the ssh_config manpage.

custom_item_629.description: GEN005511 - The SSH client must be configured to not use CBC-based ciphers.
custom_item_629.info: The Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen plain text attacks and must not be used.
custom_item_629.solution: Edit /etc/ssh/ssh_config and add or edit the 'Ciphers' line.  Only include ciphers that start with '3des' or 'aes' and do not contain 'cbc'.  For the list of available ciphers for the particular version of your software, consult the ssh_config manpage.

custom_item_630.description: GEN005512 - The SSH client must be configured to only use Message Authentication Codes (MACs) employing FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash algorithms.
custom_item_630.info:
DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash functions.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000250, SRG-OS-000495, SRG-OS-000500
custom_item_630.solution: Edit the SSH client configuration and remove any MACs that are not hmac-sha1 or a better hmac algorithm that is on the FIPS 140-2 approved list. If necessary, add a MACs line.

custom_item_631.description: GEN005521 - The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups.
custom_item_631.info: Restricting SSH logins to a limited group of users, such as system administrators, prevents password-guessing and other SSH attacks from reaching system accounts and other accounts not authorized for SSH access.
custom_item_631.solution: Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add an AllowGroups directive.

custom_item_632.description: GEN005522 - The SSH public host key files must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_632.info: If a public host key file is modified by an unauthorized user, the SSH service may be compromised.
custom_item_632.solution:
Change the permissions for the SSH public host key files.
# chmod 0644 /etc/ssh/*key.pub

custom_item_633.description: GEN005523 - The SSH private host key files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_633.info: If an unauthorized user obtains the private SSH host key file, the host could be impersonated.
custom_item_633.solution:
Change the permissions for the SSH private host key files.
# chmod 0600 /etc/ssh/*key

custom_item_634.description: GEN005524 - The SSH daemon must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
custom_item_634.info: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system(TM)s GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system.  GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.
custom_item_634.solution: Edit the SSH daemon configuration and set (add if necessary) a GSSAPIAuthentication directive set to no.

custom_item_635.description: GEN005525 - The SSH client must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
custom_item_635.info: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system(TM)s GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system.  GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.
custom_item_635.solution: Edit the SSH client configuration and set (add if necessary) a  GSSAPIAuthentication directive set to no.

custom_item_636.description: GEN005536 - The SSH daemon must perform strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.
custom_item_636.info: If other users have access to modify user-specific SSH configuration files, they may be able to log into the system as another user.
custom_item_636.solution: Edit the SSH daemon configuration and change the StrictModes setting value to yes or remove it entirely.

custom_item_637.description: GEN005538 - The SSH daemon must not allow rhosts RSA authentication.
custom_item_637.info: If SSH permits rhosts RSA authentication, a user may be able to log in based on the keys of the host originating the request and not any user-specific authentication.
custom_item_637.solution: Edit the SSH daemon configuration and change the RhostsRSAAuthentication setting value to no or remove it entirely.

custom_item_638.description: GEN005539 - The SSH daemon must not allow compression or must only allow compression after successful authentication.
custom_item_638.info: If compression is allowed in an SSH connection prior to authentication, vulnerabilities in the compression software could result in compromise of the system from an unauthenticated connection, potentially with root privileges.
custom_item_638.solution: Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add or edit the Compression setting value to no or delayed.

custom_item_642.description: GEN005540 - The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering - hosts.deny
custom_item_642.info: The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering to provide a layered defense against connection attempts from unauthorized addresses.
custom_item_642.solution: Add appropriate IP restrictions for SSH to the /etc/hosts.deny and/or /etc/hosts.allow files.

custom_item_644.description: GEN005540 - The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering - hosts.allow
custom_item_644.info: The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering to provide a layered defense against connection attempts from unauthorized addresses.
custom_item_644.solution: Add appropriate IP restrictions for SSH to the /etc/hosts.deny and/or /etc/hosts.allow files.

custom_item_645.description: GEN005550 - The SSH daemon must be configured with the Department of Defense (DoD) login banner - configured
custom_item_645.info:
Failure to display the DoD logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.

The SSH service must be configured to display the DoD logon warning banner through the SSH daemon configuration.

The SSH daemon may also be used to provide SFTP service.  The warning banner configuration for SSH will apply to SFTP.
custom_item_645.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add (or edit) a banner setting referencing a file containing a logon warning banner.

DoD Login Banners:

'You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.'

OR

'I've read & consent to terms in IS user agreem't.'

custom_item_646.description: GEN005550 - The SSH daemon must be configured with the Department of Defense (DoD) login banner - content
custom_item_646.info:
Failure to display the DoD logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.

The SSH service must be configured to display the DoD logon warning banner through the SSH daemon configuration.

The SSH daemon may also be used to provide SFTP service.  The warning banner configuration for SSH will apply to SFTP.
custom_item_646.solution:
Edit the SSH daemon configuration and add (or edit) a banner setting referencing a file containing a logon warning banner.

DoD Login Banners:

'You are accessing a U.S. Government (USG) Information System (IS) that is provided for USG-authorized use only.

By using this IS (which includes any device attached to this IS), you consent to the following conditions:

-The USG routinely intercepts and monitors communications on this IS for purposes including, but not limited to, penetration testing, COMSEC monitoring, network operations and defense, personnel misconduct (PM), law enforcement (LE), and counterintelligence (CI) investigations.

-At any time, the USG may inspect and seize data stored on this IS.

-Communications using, or data stored on, this IS are not private, are subject to routine monitoring, interception, and search, and may be disclosed or used for any USG-authorized purpose.

-This IS includes security measures (e.g., authentication and access controls) to protect USG interests--not for your personal benefit or privacy.

-Notwithstanding the above, using this IS does not constitute consent to PM, LE or CI investigative searching or monitoring of the content of privileged communications, or work product, related to personal representation or services by attorneys, psychotherapists, or clergy, and their assistants. Such communications and work product are private and confidential. See User Agreement for details.'

OR

'I've read & consent to terms in IS user agreem't.'

custom_item_648.description: GEN005560 - The system must be configured with a default gateway for IPv4 if the system uses IPv4, unless the system is a router.
custom_item_648.info: If a system has no default gateway defined, the system is at increased risk of man-in-the-middle, monitoring, and Denial of Service attacks.
custom_item_648.solution:
Create or edit /etc/defaultrouter to contain the default gateway address.

Procedure (for a default gateway of 192.168.3.1):
# echo '192.168.3.1' > /etc/defaultrouter

Restart the system for the setting to take effect.

custom_item_650.description: GEN005570 - The system must be configured with a default gateway for IPv6 if the system uses IPv6, unless the system is a router.
custom_item_650.info: If a system has no default gateway defined, the system is at increased risk of man-in-the-middle, monitoring, and Denial of Service attacks.
custom_item_650.solution:
Add a default route for IPv6.
# route add -inet6 defaultAdd this command to an init script.

custom_item_651.description: GEN005580 - A system used for routing must not run other network services or applications.
custom_item_651.info:
Installing extraneous software on a system designated as a dedicated router poses a security threat to the system and the network. Should an attacker gain access to the router through the unauthorized software, the entire network is susceptible to malicious activity.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_651.solution: Ensure only authorized software is loaded on a designated router.  Authorized software will be limited to the most current version of routing protocols and SSH for system administration purposes.

custom_item_652.description: GEN005590 - The system must not be running any routing protocol daemons, unless the system is a router.
custom_item_652.info: Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers.  If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.
custom_item_652.solution:
Disable any routing protocol daemons.

# svcadm disable
custom_item_652.cmd: /usr/bin/svcs -a | /usr/bin/grep online | /usr/bin/egrep '(ospf|route|bgp|zebra|quagga)' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no services found" }'

custom_item_653.description: GEN005600 - IP forwarding for IPv4 must not be enabled, unless the system is a router.
custom_item_653.info: If the system is configured for IP forwarding and is not a designated router, it could be used to bypass network security by providing a path for communication not filtered by network devices.
custom_item_653.solution:
Disable IPv4 forwarding on the system.
# svcadm disable svc:/network/ipv4-forwarding

custom_item_654.description: GEN005610 - The system must not have IP forwarding for IPv6 enabled, unless the system is an IPv6 router.
custom_item_654.info: If the system is configured for IP forwarding and is not a designated router, it could be used to bypass network security by providing a path for communication not filtered by network devices.
custom_item_654.solution:
Disable IPv6 forwarding.
# ndd -set /dev/ip6 ip6_forwarding 0
Edit startup scripts as necessary; add this command or remove commands setting the value to 1.

custom_item_655.description: GEN005740 - The NFS export configuration file must be owned by root.
custom_item_655.info: Failure to give ownership of the NFS export configuration file to root provides the designated owner and possible unauthorized users with the potential to change system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_655.solution:
Change the owner of the dfstab file to root.

Example:
# chown root /etc/dfs/dfstab

custom_item_656.description: GEN005750 - The NFS export configuration file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_656.info: Failure to give group ownership of the NFS export configuration file to root or system groups provides the designated group owner and possible unauthorized users with the potential to change system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_656.solution:
Change the group ownership of the NFS export configuration file.

Procedure:
# chgrp root /etc/dfs/dfstab

custom_item_657.description: GEN005760 - The NFS export configuration file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_657.info: Excessive permissions on the NFS export configuration file could allow unauthorized modification of the file, which could result in Denial of Service to authorized NFS exports and the creation of additional unauthorized exports.
custom_item_657.solution:
Change the permissions of the dfstab file to 664 or less permissive.

# chmod 0644 /etc/dfs/dfstab

custom_item_658.description: GEN005770 - The NFS exports configuration file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_658.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  Excessive permissions on the NFS export configuration file could allow unauthorized modification of the file, which could result in Denial of Service to authorized NFS exports and the creation of additional unauthorized exports.
custom_item_658.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/dfs/dfstab
custom_item_658.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/dfs/dfstab | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_659.description: GEN005800 - All NFS-exported system files and system directories must be owned by root.
custom_item_659.info: Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or directories  to root provides the designated owner and possible unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_659.solution:
Change the ownership of exported file systems not owned by root.

Procedure:
# chown root
custom_item_659.cmd: /usr/bin/egrep -v '^(#.*| *)$' /etc/dfs/dfstab | /usr/bin/awk '{ print $NF }' | /usr/bin/xargs ls -lLd | /usr/bin/awk '$3 !~ /^root$/ { print $3,$NF; n++ } END { if (!n) print "no shares found" }'

custom_item_660.description: GEN005810 - All NFS exported system files and system directories must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_660.info: Failure to give group ownership of sensitive files or directories to root provides the members of the owning group with the potential to access sensitive information or change system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.
custom_item_660.solution:
Change the group owner of the export directory.
# chgrp root
custom_item_660.cmd: /usr/bin/egrep -v '^(#.*| *)$' /etc/dfs/dfstab | /usr/bin/awk '{ print $NF }' | /usr/bin/xargs ls -lLd | /usr/bin/awk '$4 !~ /^(root|bin|sys)$/ { print $4,$NF } END { if (!n) print "no shares found" }'

custom_item_661.description: GEN005820 - The NFS anonymous UID and GID must be configured to values that have no permissions.
custom_item_661.info: When an NFS server is configured to deny remote root access, a selected UID and GID are used to handle requests from the remote root user.  The UID and GID should be chosen from the system to provide the appropriate level of non-privileged access.
custom_item_661.solution: Edit /etc/dfs/dfstab and add the 'anon=-1' option for exports lacking it.  Re-export the filesystems.

custom_item_662.description: GEN005840 - The NFS server must be configured to restrict file system access to local hosts.
custom_item_662.info: The NFS access option limits user access to the specified level. This assists in protecting exported file systems.  If access is not restricted, unauthorized hosts may be able to access the system's NFS exports.
custom_item_662.solution: Edit /etc/dfs/dfstab and add ro and/or rw options (as appropriate) specifying a list of hosts or networks which are permitted access.  Re-export the file systems.

custom_item_663.description: GEN005860 - The system's NFS export configuration must not have the sec option set to none (or equivalent); additionally, the default authentication must not to be set to none - nfssec.conf default
custom_item_663.info: If sec=none on Solaris, all NFS requests are mapped to an unknown/common user instead of being processed according to the provided UID.
custom_item_663.solution: Edit the /etc/dfs/dfstab file and add the sec=XXX option to the share line as an option.  XXX must be a valid option for the system other than none.

custom_item_664.description: GEN005860 - The system's NFS export configuration must not have the sec option set to none (or equivalent); additionally, the default authentication must not to be set to none - sec=none
custom_item_664.info: If sec=none on Solaris, all NFS requests are mapped to an unknown/common user instead of being processed according to the provided UID.
custom_item_664.solution: Edit the /etc/dfs/dfstab file and add the sec=XXX option to the share line as an option.  XXX must be a valid option for the system other than none.

custom_item_665.description: GEN005880 - The NFS server must not allow remote root access.
custom_item_665.info: If the NFS server allows root access to local file systems from remote hosts, this access could be used to compromise the system.
custom_item_665.solution: Edit the /etc/dfs/dfstab file and remove the root= option from all exports.  Re-export the file systems.

custom_item_666.description: GEN005900 - The nosuid option must be enabled on all NFS client mounts.
custom_item_666.info: Enabling the nosuid mount option prevents the system from granting owner or group-owner privileges to programs with the setuid or setgid bit set.  If the system does not restrict this access, users with unprivileged access to the local system may be able to acquire privileged access by executing setuid or setgid files located on the mounted NFS file system.
custom_item_666.solution: Edit /etc/vfstab and add the nosuid option for all NFS file systems. Remount the NFS file systems to make the change take effect.

custom_item_667.description: GEN006060 - The system must not run Samba unless needed.
custom_item_667.info: Samba is a tool used for the sharing of files and printers between Windows and UNIX operating systems.  It provides access to sensitive files and, therefore, poses a security risk if compromised.
custom_item_667.solution: If there is no functional need for Samba and the daemon is running, disable the daemon by killing the process ID as noted from the output of ps -ef |grep smbd.  The utility should also be removed or not installed if there is no functional requirement.

custom_item_669.description: GEN006080 - The Samba Web Administration Tool (SWAT) must be restricted to the local host or require SSL - TCP_Wrappers
custom_item_669.info:
SWAT is a tool used to configure Samba. As it modifies Samba configuration, which can impact system security, it must be protected from unauthorized access. SWAT authentication may involve the root password, which must be protected by encryption when traversing the network.

Restricting access to the local host allows for the use of SSH TCP forwarding, if configured, or administration by a web browser on the local system.
custom_item_669.solution:
Enable tcp_wrappers for the SWAT daemon.
# inetadm -m swat tcp_wrappers=true
  OR
# inetadm -M tcp_wrappers=true
Relfresh the inetd daemon.
# svcadm refresh inetd

Configure the hosts.allow and hosts.deny files to limit access to SWAT to localhost.
Example:
# echo ALL: ALL >> /etc/hosts.deny
# echo swat: localhost >> /etc/hosts.allow

custom_item_670.description: GEN006080 - The Samba Web Administration Tool (SWAT) must be restricted to the local host or require SSL - hosts.allow
custom_item_670.info:
SWAT is a tool used to configure Samba. As it modifies Samba configuration, which can impact system security, it must be protected from unauthorized access. SWAT authentication may involve the root password, which must be protected by encryption when traversing the network.

Restricting access to the local host allows for the use of SSH TCP forwarding, if configured, or administration by a web browser on the local system.
custom_item_670.solution:
Enable tcp_wrappers for the SWAT daemon.
# inetadm -m swat tcp_wrappers=true
  OR
# inetadm -M tcp_wrappers=true
Relfresh the inetd daemon.
# svcadm refresh inetd

Configure the hosts.allow and hosts.deny files to limit access to SWAT to localhost.
Example:
# echo ALL: ALL >> /etc/hosts.deny
# echo swat: localhost >> /etc/hosts.allow

custom_item_671.description: GEN006080 - The Samba Web Administration Tool (SWAT) must be restricted to the local host or require SSL - hosts.deny
custom_item_671.info:
SWAT is a tool used to configure Samba. As it modifies Samba configuration, which can impact system security, it must be protected from unauthorized access. SWAT authentication may involve the root password, which must be protected by encryption when traversing the network.

Restricting access to the local host allows for the use of SSH TCP forwarding, if configured, or administration by a web browser on the local system.
custom_item_671.solution:
Enable tcp_wrappers for the SWAT daemon.
# inetadm -m swat tcp_wrappers=true
  OR
# inetadm -M tcp_wrappers=true
Relfresh the inetd daemon.
# svcadm refresh inetd

Configure the hosts.allow and hosts.deny files to limit access to SWAT to localhost.
Example:
# echo ALL: ALL >> /etc/hosts.deny
# echo swat: localhost >> /etc/hosts.allow

custom_item_672.description: GEN006100 - The smb.conf file must be owned by root.
custom_item_672.info: The smb.conf file allows access to other machines on the network and grants permissions to certain users.  If it is owned by another user, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.
custom_item_672.solution:
Change the ownership of the smb.conf file.

Procedure:
# chown root /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf

custom_item_673.description: GEN006120 - The smb.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
custom_item_673.info: If the group owner of the smb.conf file is not root or a system group, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.
custom_item_673.solution:
Change the group owner of the smb.conf file.

Procedure:

# chgrp root /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf

custom_item_674.description: GEN006140 - The smb.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
custom_item_674.info: If the smb.conf file has excessive permissions, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.
custom_item_674.solution:
Change the mode of the smb.conf file to 0644 or less permissive.

Procedure:
# chmod 0644 /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf

custom_item_675.description: GEN006150 - The smb.conf file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_675.info: Excessive permissions could endanger the security of the Samba configuration file and, ultimately, the system and network.
custom_item_675.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/smb.conf /etc/sfw/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/sfw/samba/smb.conf
custom_item_675.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd @SMB_CONF@ | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_676.description: GEN006160 - The smbpasswd file must be owned by root.
custom_item_676.info: If the smbpasswd file is not owned by root, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_676.solution:
Use the chown command to configure the smb passwd file.
# chown root /etc/sfw/private/smbpasswd

custom_item_677.description: GEN006180 - The smbpasswd file must be group-owned by root.
custom_item_677.info: If the smbpasswd file is not group-owned by root, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_677.solution:
Use the chgrp command to ensure the group owner of the smbpasswd file is root.

# chgrp root /etc/sfw/private/smbpasswd

custom_item_678.description: GEN006200 - The smbpasswd file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_678.info: If the smbpasswd file has a mode more permissive than 0600, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_678.solution:
Change the mode of the smbpasswd file to 0600.

Procedure:
# chmod 0600 /etc/sfw/private/smbpasswd

custom_item_679.description: GEN006210 - The smbpasswd file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_679.info: If the permissions of the smbpasswd file are too permissive, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.
custom_item_679.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/sfw/private/smbpasswd
custom_item_679.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/sfw/private/smbpasswd | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_680.description: GEN006220 - The smb.conf file must use the hosts option to restrict access to Samba.
custom_item_680.info: Samba increases the attack surface of the system and must be restricted to communicate only with systems requiring access.
custom_item_680.solution: Edit the smb.conf file and set the hosts option to permit only authorized hosts to access Samba.

custom_item_681.description: GEN006225 - Samba must be configured to use an authentication mechanism other than 'share.' - share.
custom_item_681.info: Samba share authentication does not provide for individual user identification and must not be used.
custom_item_681.solution: Edit the smb.conf file and change the security setting to user or another valid setting other than share.

custom_item_682.description: GEN006230 - Samba must be configured to use encrypted passwords.
custom_item_682.info: Samba must be configured to protect authenticators.  If Samba passwords are not encrypted for storage, plain-text user passwords may be read by those with access to the Samba password file.
custom_item_682.solution: Edit the smb.conf file and change the encrypt passwords setting to yes.

custom_item_683.description: GEN006235 - Samba must be configured to not allow guest access to shares.
custom_item_683.info: Guest access to shares permits anonymous access and is not permitted.
custom_item_683.solution: Edit the smb.conf file and change the guest ok setting to no.

custom_item_684.description: GEN006240 - The system must not run an Internet Network News (INN) server.
custom_item_684.info:
Internet Network News (INN) servers access Usenet newsfeeds and store newsgroup articles.  INN servers use the Network News Transfer Protocol (NNTP) to transfer information from the Usenet to the server and from the server to authorized remote hosts.

If this function is necessary to support a valid mission requirement, its use must be authorized and approved in the system accreditation package.
custom_item_684.cmd: /usr/bin/ps -ef | /usr/bin/egrep 'innd|nntpd' | /usr/bin/grep -v /usr/bin/egrep 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no processes found" }'

custom_item_685.description: GEN006260 - The /etc/news/hosts.nntp (or equivalent) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_685.info: Excessive permissions on the hosts.nntp file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial-of-Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_685.solution:
Change the mode of the /etc/news/hosts.nntp file to 0600.

# chmod 0600 /etc/news/hosts.nntp

custom_item_686.description: GEN006270 - The /etc/news/hosts.nntp file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_686.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  Excessive permissions on the hosts.nntp file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_686.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/news/hosts.nntp
custom_item_686.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/news/hosts.nntp | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_687.description: GEN006280 - The /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit (or equivalent) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_687.info: Excessive permissions on the hosts.nntp.nolimit file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial-of-Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_687.solution:
Change the mode of /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit to 0600.
# chmod 0600 /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit

custom_item_688.description: GEN006290 - The /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_688.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  Excessive permissions on the hosts.nntp.nolimit file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_688.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit
custom_item_688.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/news/hosts.nntp.nolimit | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_689.description: GEN006300 - The /etc/news/nnrp.access (or equivalent) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_689.info: Excessive permissions on the nnrp.access file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial-of-Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_689.solution:
Change the mode of the /etc/news/nnrp.access file to 0600.
# chmod 0600 /etc/news/nnrp.access

custom_item_690.description: GEN006310 - The /etc/news/nnrp.access file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_690.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  Excessive permissions on the nnrp.access file may allow unauthorized modification which could lead to Denial of Service to authorized users or provide access to unauthorized users.
custom_item_690.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/news/nnrp.access
custom_item_690.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/news/nnrp.access | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_691.description: GEN006320 - The /etc/news/passwd.nntp file (or equivalent) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_691.info: File permissions more permissive than 0600 for /etc/news/passwd.nntp may allow access to privileged information by system intruders or malicious users.
custom_item_691.solution:
Change the mode of the /etc/news/passwd.nntp file.
# chmod 0600 /etc/news/passwd.nntp

custom_item_692.description: GEN006330 - The /etc/news/passwd.nntp file must not have an extended ACL.
custom_item_692.info: Extended ACLs may provide excessive permissions on the  /etc/news/passwd.nntp file, which may permit unauthorized  access or modification to the NNTP configuration.
custom_item_692.solution:
Remove the extended ACL from the file.
# chmod A- /etc/news/passwd.nntp
custom_item_692.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd /etc/news/passwd.nntp | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_693.description: GEN006340 - Files in /etc/news must be owned by root - /etc/news
custom_item_693.info: If critical system files are not owned by a privileged user, system integrity could be compromised.
custom_item_693.solution:
Change the ownership of the /etc/news directory and the files in it to root.

Procedure:
# chown -R root /etc/news

custom_item_694.description: GEN006340 - Files in /etc/news must be owned by root - /etc/news/*
custom_item_694.info: If critical system files are not owned by a privileged user, system integrity could be compromised.
custom_item_694.solution:
Change the ownership of the /etc/news directory and the files in it to root.

Procedure:
# chown -R root /etc/news

custom_item_695.description: GEN006360 - The files in /etc/news must be group-owned by root - /etc/news
custom_item_695.info: If critical system files do not have a privileged group owner, system integrity could be compromised.
custom_item_695.solution:
Change the group owner of the /etc/news directory and the files in it to root.

Procedure:
# chgrp -R root /etc/news

custom_item_696.description: GEN006360 - The files in /etc/news must be group-owned by root - /etc/news/*
custom_item_696.info: If critical system files do not have a privileged group owner, system integrity could be compromised.
custom_item_696.solution:
Change the group owner of the /etc/news directory and the files in it to root.

Procedure:
# chgrp -R root /etc/news

custom_item_697.description: GEN006380 - The system must not use UDP for NIS/NIS+.
custom_item_697.info: Implementing NIS or NIS+ under UDP may make the system more susceptible to a Denial of Service attack and does not provide the same quality of service as TCP.
custom_item_697.solution: Configure the system to not use UDP for NIS and NIS+.  Consult vendor documentation for the required procedure.
custom_item_697.cmd: /usr/bin/rpcinfo -p | /usr/bin/grep yp | /usr/bin/grep udp 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no services found" }'

custom_item_698.description: GEN006400 - The Network Information System (NIS) protocol must not be used.
custom_item_698.info: Due to numerous security vulnerabilities existing within NIS, it must not be used.  Possible alternative directory services are NIS+ and LDAP.
custom_item_698.solution: Disable the use of NIS.  Possible replacements are NIS+ and LDAP.
custom_item_698.cmd: /usr/bin/ps -ef | /usr/bin/egrep '(ypbind|ypserv)' | /usr/bin/grep -v /usr/bin/egrep 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no processes found" }'

custom_item_699.description: GEN006420 - NIS maps must be protected through hard-to-guess domain names.
custom_item_699.info:
The use of hard-to-guess NIS domain names provides additional protection from unauthorized access to the NIS directory information.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_699.solution: Change the NIS domain name to a value difficult to guess.  Consult vendor documentation for the required procedure.
custom_item_699.cmd: /usr/bin/domainname 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ if (NF == 0) print "no domain name set"; else print }'

custom_item_700.description: GEN006460 - Any NIS+ server must be operating at security level 2.
custom_item_700.info: If the NIS+ server is not operating in, at least, security level 2, there is no encryption and the system could be penetrated by intruders and/or malicious users.
custom_item_700.solution:
Ensure the NIS+ server is operating at security level 2 by editing /usr/lib/nis/nisserver and ensuring the line containing SEC= is set to the numeral 2, for example:

SEC=2                   # 2=DES or 3=RSA

Security Level 0 is designed for testing and initial setup of the NIS+ namespace.  When running at level 0, the daemon does not enforce access control.  Any client is allowed to perform any operation, including updates and deletions.

Security level 1 accepts AUTH_SYS and AUTH_DES credentials for authenticating clients and authorizing them to perform NIS+ operations.  This is not a secure mode of operation since AUTH_SYS credentials are easily forged.  It should not be used on networks in which any untrusted user may potentially have access.  Security level 2 accepts only AUTH_DES credentials for authentication and authorization.  This is the highest level of security currently provided by the NIS+ service and the default security level if the -S option is not used.

custom_item_701.description: GEN006565 - The system package management tool must be used to verify system software periodically.
custom_item_701.info:
Verification using the system package management tool can be used to determine that system software has not been tampered with.

This requirement is not applicable to systems not using package management tools.
custom_item_701.solution: Add a cron job to run a package verification command, such as, pkgchk -n.

custom_item_703.description: GEN006570 - The file integrity tool must be configured to verify ACLs - config
custom_item_703.info: ACLs can provide permissions beyond those permitted through the file mode and must be verified by file integrity tools.
custom_item_703.solution:
If using AIDE, edit the configuration and add the acl option for all monitored files and directories.

If using a different file integrity tool, configure ACL checking per the tool's documentation.

custom_item_704.description: GEN006570 - The file integrity tool must be configured to verify ACLs - used
custom_item_704.info: ACLs can provide permissions beyond those permitted through the file mode and must be verified by file integrity tools.
custom_item_704.solution:
If using AIDE, edit the configuration and add the acl option for all monitored files and directories.

If using a different file integrity tool, configure ACL checking per the tool's documentation.

custom_item_705.description: GEN006571 - The file integrity tool must be configured to verify extended attributes - config
custom_item_705.info: Extended attributes in file systems are used to contain arbitrary data and file metadata with security implications.
custom_item_705.solution:
If using AIDE, edit the configuration and add the xattrs option for all monitored files and directories.

If using a different file integrity tool, configure extended attributes checking per the tool's documentation.

custom_item_706.description: GEN006571 - The file integrity tool must be configured to verify extended attributes - used
custom_item_706.info: Extended attributes in file systems are used to contain arbitrary data and file metadata with security implications.
custom_item_706.solution:
If using AIDE, edit the configuration and add the xattrs option for all monitored files and directories.

If using a different file integrity tool, configure extended attributes checking per the tool's documentation.

custom_item_707.description: GEN006575 - The file integrity tool must use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes for validating file contents - config
custom_item_707.info: File integrity tools often use cryptographic hashes for verifying that file contents have not been altered.  These hashes must be FIPS 140-2 approved.
custom_item_707.solution:
If using AIDE, edit the configuration and add the sha256 or sha512 option for all monitored files and directories.

If using a different file integrity tool, configure FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes per the tool's documentation.

custom_item_708.description: GEN006575 - The file integrity tool must use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes for validating file contents - used
custom_item_708.info: File integrity tools often use cryptographic hashes for verifying that file contents have not been altered.  These hashes must be FIPS 140-2 approved.
custom_item_708.solution:
If using AIDE, edit the configuration and add the sha256 or sha512 option for all monitored files and directories.

If using a different file integrity tool, configure FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes per the tool's documentation.

custom_item_709.description: GEN006580 - The system must use an access control program.
custom_item_709.info: Access control programs (such as TCP_WRAPPERS) provide the ability to enhance system security posture.
custom_item_709.solution:
Enable tcp_wrappers.
# svccfg -s svc:/network/inetd setprop defaults/tcp_wrappers=true
# svcadm refresh inetd

custom_item_710.description: GEN006600 - The system's access control program must log each system access attempt.
custom_item_710.info: If access attempts are not logged, then multiple attempts to log on to the system by an unauthorized user may go undetected.
custom_item_710.solution: Configure the access restriction program to log every access attempt.  Ensure the implementation instructions for TCP_WRAPPERS are followed, so system access attempts are logged into the system log files.  If an alternate application is used, it must support this function.

custom_item_711.description: GEN006620 - The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts - host.allow
custom_item_711.info: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.
custom_item_711.solution: Edit the /etc/hosts.allow and /etc/hosts.deny files to configure access restrictions.

custom_item_712.description: GEN006620 - The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts - host.deny
custom_item_712.info: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.
custom_item_712.solution: Edit the /etc/hosts.allow and /etc/hosts.deny files to configure access restrictions.

custom_item_713.description: GEN006620 - The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts - default deny
custom_item_713.info: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.
custom_item_713.solution: Edit the /etc/hosts.allow and /etc/hosts.deny files to configure access restrictions.

custom_item_714.description: GEN006640 - The system must use and update a DoD-approved virus scan program. 'daily uvscan'

custom_item_715.description: GEN006640 - The system must use and update a DoD-approved virus scan program. '*.dat age'

custom_item_716.description: GEN006640 - The system must use a virus scan program.
custom_item_716.info: Virus scanning software can be used to protect a system from penetration by computer viruses and to limit their spread through intermediate systems.
custom_item_716.solution: The operator will ensure that anti-virus software is installed and operating.

custom_item_718.description: GEN007480 - The Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) protocol must be disabled or not installed unless required.
custom_item_718.info:
The Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) protocol is a relatively new protocol developed by Oracle for communication between the nodes of a cluster.  Binding this protocol to the network stack increases the attack surface of the host.  Unprivileged local processes may be able to cause the system to dynamically load a protocol handler by opening a socket using the protocol.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000096, SRG-OS-000510
custom_item_718.solution:
Remove the RDS protocol handler package.
# pkgrm SUNWrds

OR

Prevent the RDS protocol handler from dynamic loading.
# echo 'exclude: rds' >> /etc/system

custom_item_720.description: GEN007540 - The Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC) protocol must be disabled or not installed.
custom_item_720.info:
The Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC) protocol is a relatively new cluster communications protocol developed by Ericsson.  Binding this protocol to the network stack increases the attack surface of the host.   Unprivileged local processes may be able to cause the kernel to dynamically load a protocol handler by opening a socket using the protocol.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000096, SRG-OS-000510
custom_item_720.solution:
Remove the TIPC protocol handler package.
# pkgrm SUNWtipc

OR

Prevent the TIPC protocol handler from dynamic loading.
# echo 'exclude: tipc' >> /etc/system

custom_item_721.description: GEN007780 - The system must not have 6to4 enabled.
custom_item_721.info:
6to4 is an IPv6 transition mechanism that involves tunneling IPv6 packets encapsulated in IPv4 packets on an ad-hoc basis.  This is not a preferred transition strategy and increases the attack surface of the system.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_721.solution:
Disable the active 6to4 tunnel.
# ifconfigdown

Check the /etc/hostname* files for startup configuration for the tunnel, and edit or delete as appropriate to prevent the tunnel creation on startup.
custom_item_721.cmd: /usr/sbin/ifconfig -a6 | /usr/bin/egrep '^[a-z\.]+tun' | /usr/bin/cut -f1 -d: | /usr/bin/xargs -IINT ifconfig INT inet6 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no ipv6 tunnel configured" }'

custom_item_722.description: GEN007820 - The system must not have IP tunnels configured.
custom_item_722.info: IP tunneling mechanisms can be used to bypass network filtering.
custom_item_722.solution:
Disable the tunnels.
# ifconfigdown
Remove the startup configuration for the tunnels.
# rm /etc/hostname.
custom_item_722.cmd: /usr/sbin/ifconfig -a | /usr/bin/grep 'ip.*tun' 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no tunnel configured" }'

custom_item_723.description: GEN007840 - The DHCP client must be disabled if not needed.
custom_item_723.info: DHCP allows for the unauthenticated configuration of network parameters on the system by exchanging information with a DHCP server.
custom_item_723.solution:
Delete the DHCP client configuration.
# rm /etc/dhcp.*

custom_item_724.description: GEN007841 - Wireless network adapters must be disabled.
custom_item_724.info:
The use of wireless networking can introduce many different attack vectors into the organization's network. Common attack vectors such as malicious association and ad hoc networks will allow an attacker to spoof a wireless access point (AP), allowing validated systems to connect to the malicious AP and enabling the attacker to monitor and record network traffic. These malicious APs can also serve to create a man-in-the-middle attack or be used to create a denial of service to valid network resources.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_724.solution: Configure the system to disable all wireless network interfaces.

custom_item_725.description: GEN007860 - The system must ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages - dladm show-link
custom_item_725.info:
ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_725.solution:
Configure the system to ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.
# ndd -set /dev/ip6 ip6_ignore_redirect 1
Also add this command to a system startup script.

custom_item_726.description: GEN007860 - The system must ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.
custom_item_726.info: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.
custom_item_726.solution:
Configure the system to ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.
# ndd -set /dev/ip6 ip6_ignore_redirect 1
Also add this command to a system startup script.

custom_item_727.description: GEN007880 - The system must not send IPv6 ICMP redirects.
custom_item_727.info: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table revealing  portions of the network topology.
custom_item_727.solution:
Configure the system to not send IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.
# ndd -set /dev/ip6 ip6_send_redirects 0

Also, add this command to a system startup script.

custom_item_728.description: GEN007880 - The system must not send IPv6 ICMP redirects - dladm show-link
custom_item_728.info:
ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table revealing  portions of the network topology.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_728.solution:
Configure the system to not send IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.
# ndd -set /dev/ip6 ip6_send_redirects 0

Also, add this command to a system startup script.

custom_item_729.description: GEN007920 - The system must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets - ip6_forward_src_routed
custom_item_729.info: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures.  This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when IPv6 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
custom_item_729.solution:
Configure the system to not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.
# ndd -set /dev/ip6 ip6_forward_src_routed 0

Also, add this command to a system startup script.

custom_item_730.description: GEN007920 - The system must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets - dladm show-link
custom_item_730.info:
Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures.  This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when IPv6 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_730.solution:
Configure the system to not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.
# ndd -set /dev/ip6 ip6_forward_src_routed 0

Also, add this command to a system startup script.

custom_item_731.description: GEN007950 - The system must not respond to ICMPv6 echo requests sent to a broadcast address.
custom_item_731.info: Responding to broadcast ICMP echo requests facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.
custom_item_731.solution:
Configure the system to not respond to IPv6 multicast ICMP echo-requests.

Procedure:
# ndd -set /dev/ip ip6_respond_to_echo_multicast 0

This command must also be added to a system startup script.

custom_item_732.description: GEN007950 - The system must not respond to ICMPv6 echo requests sent to a broadcast address - dladm show-link
custom_item_732.info:
Responding to broadcast ICMP echo requests facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_732.solution:
Configure the system to not respond to IPv6 multicast ICMP echo-requests.

Procedure:
# ndd -set /dev/ip ip6_respond_to_echo_multicast 0

This command must also be added to a system startup script.

custom_item_734.description: GEN007980 - If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the system must use a TLS connection using FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic algorithms - configured
custom_item_734.info:
LDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. Communication between an LDAP server and a host using LDAP requires protection.

Satisfies: SRG-OS-000250, SRG-OS-000495, SRG-OS-000500
custom_item_734.solution: Configure all LDAP authentications and connections to be encrypted using TLS and FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic algorithms.

custom_item_735.cmd: /usr/bin/grep NS_LDAP_SERVERS= /var/ldap/client_file 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no servers found" }'

custom_item_736.description: GEN008060 - If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information the LDAP client configuration file must have mode 0600 or less permissive - /var/ldap/ldap_client_file

custom_item_742.description: GEN008120 - If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the /etc/ldap.conf (or equivalent) file must not have an extended ACL - ldap_client_file
custom_item_742.info: LDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security.  The LDAP client configuration must be protected from unauthorized modification.

custom_item_754.description: GEN008440 - Automated file system mounting tools must not be enabled unless needed.
custom_item_754.info: Automated file system mounting tools may provide unprivileged users with the ability to access local media and network shares.  If this access is not necessary for the system(TM)s operation, it must be disabled to reduce the risk of unauthorized access to these resources.
custom_item_754.solution:
Stop and disable the autofs service.
# svcadm disable autofs

custom_item_755.description: GEN008460 - The system must have USB disabled unless needed.
custom_item_755.info: USB is a common computer peripheral interface.  USB devices may include storage devices that could be used to install malicious software on a system or exfiltrate data.
custom_item_755.solution:
Remove the SUNWusb package.
# pkgrm SUNWusb
custom_item_755.cmd: /usr/bin/pkginfo | /usr/bin/grep SUNWusb 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no packages found" }'

custom_item_756.description: GEN008480 - The system must have USB Mass Storage disabled unless needed - modinfo
custom_item_756.info: USB is a common computer peripheral interface.  USB devices may include storage devices that could be used to install malicious software on a system or exfiltrate data.
custom_item_756.solution:
Prevent the USB drivers from loading:
# echo 'exclude: usb_ac' >> /etc/system
# echo 'exclude: usb_as' >> /etc/system
# echo 'exclude: hid' >> /etc/system
# echo 'exclude: scsa2usb' >> /etc/system
# echo 'exclude: usbprn' >> /etc/system
# echo 'exclude: usbser_edge' >> /etc/system

The system must be restarted for these changes to take effect.

custom_item_757.description: GEN008480 - The system must have USB Mass Storage disabled unless needed - system

custom_item_758.description: GEN008500 - The system must have IEEE 1394 (Firewire) disabled unless needed.
custom_item_758.info: Firewire is a common computer peripheral interface.  Firewire devices may include storage devices that could be used to install malicious software on a system or exfiltrate data.
custom_item_758.solution:

custom_item_760.description: GEN008520 - The system must employ a local firewall.
custom_item_760.info:
A local firewall protects the system from exposing unnecessary or undocumented network services to the local enclave.  If a system within the enclave is compromised, firewall protection on an individual system continues to protect it from attack.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_760.solution:
Enable the system's local firewall.
# svcadm enable network/ipfilter

custom_item_761.description: GEN008540 - The system's local firewall must implement a deny-all, allow-by-exception policy.
custom_item_761.info:
A local firewall protects the system from exposing unnecessary or undocumented network services to the local enclave.  If a system within the enclave is compromised, firewall protection on an individual system continues to protect it from attack.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_761.solution:
Edit /etc/ipf/ipf.conf and add a default deny rule.
Restart the ipfilter service.
# svcadm restart network/ipfilter
custom_item_761.cmd: /usr/sbin/ipfstat -i 2>&1 | /usr/bin/awk '{ print } END { if (NR == 0) print "no rules found" }'

custom_item_762.description: GEN008660 - For systems capable of using GRUB, the system must be configured with GRUB as the default boot loader unless another boot loader has been authorized, justified, and documented using site-defined procedures.
custom_item_762.info: GRUB is a versatile boot loader used by several platforms providing authentication for access to the system or boot loader.
custom_item_762.solution: Configure the system to use the GRUB bootloader.

custom_item_763.description: GEN008700 - The system boot loader must require authentication.
custom_item_763.info: If the system's boot loader does not require authentication, users with console access to the system may be able to alter the system boot configuration or boot the system into single user or maintenance mode, which could result in Denial-of-Service or unauthorized privileged access to the system.
custom_item_763.solution: The GRUB console boot loader can be configured to use an MD5 encrypted password by adding password --md5 password-hash to the /pool-name/boot/grub/menu.lst or /boot/grub/menu.lst file. Use grub-md5-crypt to generate MD5 passwords from the command line.

custom_item_764.description: GEN008720 - The system's boot loader configuration file(s) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
custom_item_764.info: File permissions greater than 0600 on boot loader configuration files could allow an unauthorized user to view or modify sensitive information pertaining to system boot instructions.
custom_item_764.solution:
Change the mode of the menu.lst file to 0600.

# chmod 0600 /pool-name/boot/grub/menu.lst
or
# chmod 0600 /boot/grub/menu.lst

custom_item_765.description: GEN003540 - The system must implement non-executable program stacks.
custom_item_765.info: A common type of exploit is the stack buffer overflow.  An application receives, from an attacker, more data than it is prepared for and stores this information on its stack, writing beyond the space reserved for it.  This can be designed to cause execution of the data written on the stack.  One mechanism to mitigate this vulnerability is for the system to not allow the execution of instructions in sections of memory identified as part of the stack.
custom_item_765.solution:
This action applies to the global zone only. Determine the type of zone that you are currently securing.

# zonename

If the command output is 'global', this action applies.

Edit /etc/system and set the noexec_user_stack parameter to 1.  Restart the system for the setting to take effect.

custom_item_766.description: GEN000240 - The system clock must be synchronized to an authoritative DoD time source.
custom_item_766.info:
To ensure the accuracy of the system clock, it must be synchronized with an authoritative time source within DoD. Many system functions, including time-based login and activity restrictions, automated reports, system logs, and audit records depend on an accurate system clock. If there is no confidence in the correctness of the system clock, time-based functions may not operate as intended and records may be of diminished value.

Authoritative time sources include authorized time servers within the enclave that synchronize with upstream authoritative sources. Specific requirements for the upstream synchronization of Network Time Protocol (NTP) servers are covered in the Network Other Devices STIG.

For systems located on isolated or closed networks, it is not necessary to synchronize with a global authoritative time source. If a global authoritative time source is not available to systems on an isolated network, a local authoritative time source must be established on this network and used by the systems connected to this network. This is necessary to provide the ability to correlate events and allow for the correct operation of time-dependent protocols between systems on the isolated network.

If the system is completely isolated (no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events between systems will be necessary. If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.
custom_item_766.solution: Use a local authoritative time server synchronizing to an authorized DoD time source. Ensure all systems in the facility feed from one or more local time servers that feed from the authoritative time server.

custom_item_767.description: GEN000241 - The system clock must be synchronized continuously.
custom_item_767.info:
A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. Internal system clocks tend to drift and require periodic resynchronization to ensure their accuracy. Software, such as NTPD, can be used to continuously synchronize the system clock with authoritative sources. Alternatively, the system may be synchronized periodically, with a maximum of one day between synchronizations.

If the system is completely isolated (no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events or operation of time-dependent protocols between systems will be necessary. If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.
custom_item_767.solution:
Determine the type of zone currently being secured.

# zonename

If the command output is not 'global', then NTP and NTP4 must be disabled.

# svcadm disable ntp
# svcadm disable ntp4

If the output from 'zonename' is 'global', then NTP or NTP4 must be enabled.

# svcadm enable ntp
or
# svcadm enable ntp4

custom_item_768.description: GEN000244 - The system must use time sources local to the enclave.
custom_item_768.info:
A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  The network architecture should provide multiple time servers within an enclave that provide local service to the enclave and synchronize with time sources outside of the enclave.

If this server is an enclave time server, this requirement is not applicable.

If the system is completely isolated (no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events or operation of time-dependent protocols between systems will be necessary.  If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.
custom_item_768.solution: Remove the server line from /etc/inet/ntp.conf for each NTP server that is external to the enclave.

custom_item_769.description: ntp is running as a service

custom_item_770.description: GEN000242 - The system must use at least two time sources for clock synchronization - service ntp server 1
custom_item_770.info:
A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  For redundancy, two time sources are required so synchronization continues to function if one source fails.

If the system is completely isolated (no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events or operation of time-dependent protocols between systems will be necessary.  If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.

NOTE:  For the Network Time Protocol (NTP), the requirement is two servers, but it is recommended to configure at least four distinct time servers which allow NTP to effectively exclude a time source not consistent with the others.  The system's local clock must be excluded from the count of time sources.
custom_item_770.solution: Add an additional server line to /etc/inet/ntp.conf for each additional NTP server.

custom_item_771.description: GEN000242 - The system must use at least two time sources for clock synchronization - service ntp server 2
custom_item_771.info:
A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems.  For redundancy, two time sources are required so synchronization continues to function if one source fails.

If the system is completely isolated (no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events or operation of time-dependent protocols between systems will be necessary.  If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.

NOTE:  For the Network Time Protocol (NTP), the requirement is two servers, but it is recommended to configure at least four distinct time servers which allow NTP to effectively exclude a time source not consistent with the others.  The system's local clock must be excluded from the count of time sources.
custom_item_771.solution: Add an additional server line to /etc/inet/ntp.conf for each additional NTP server.

custom_item_772.description: GEN008740 - The system's boot loader configuration file(s) must not have extended ACLs.
custom_item_772.info: File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the mode numbers of the files.  If extended ACLs are present on the system's boot loader configuration file(s), these files may be vulnerable to unauthorized access or modification, which could compromise the system's boot process.
custom_item_772.solution:
If the file with the extended ACL resides on a UFS filesystem:
# getfacl /boot/grub/menu.lst

Remove each ACE from the file.
# setfacl -r [ACE] /boot/grub/menu.lst

If the file with the extended ACL resides on a ZFS filesystem:
# chmod A- /pool-name/boot/grub/menu.lst
custom_item_772.cmd: /usr/bin/ls -lLd @GRUB_CONF@ | /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN { n=0 } substr($0,11,1) == "+" { n++; print $1,$NF } END { print "ACL found: "n }'

custom_item_773.description: GEN008760 - The system's boot loader configuration files must be owned by root.
custom_item_773.info: The system's boot loader configuration files are critical to the integrity of the system and must be protected.  Unauthorized modification of these files resulting from improper ownership could compromise the system's boot loader configuration.
custom_item_773.solution:
Change the ownership of the file.
# chown root /pool-name/boot/grub/menu.lst
or
# chown root /boot/grub/menu.lst

custom_item_774.description: GEN008780 - The system's boot loader configuration file(s) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
custom_item_774.info: The system's boot loader configuration files are critical to the integrity of the system and must be protected.  Unauthorized modifications resulting from improper group ownership may compromise the boot loader configuration.
custom_item_774.solution:
Change the group ownership of the file.
# chgrp root /pool-name/boot/grub/menu.lst
or
# chgrp root /boot/grub/menu.lst

custom_item_775.description: GEN008710 - The system boot loader must protect passwords using an MD5 or stronger cryptographic hash.
custom_item_775.info: If system boot loader passwords are compromised, users with console access to the system may be able to alter the system boot configuration or boot the system into single user or maintenance mode, which could result in Denial-of-Service or unauthorized privileged access to the system.
custom_item_775.solution:
Configure the GRUB bootloader to require a password.

Procedure:

Obtain the location of the active GRUB menu file.
# bootadm list-menu

Create a password hash using GRUB. The location of the GRUB binary may be different based on the specific system.
# /boot/grub/bin/grub
grub> md5crypt
Password:Encrypted:grub> quit

The encrypted password hash will be returned.

Edit the GRUB menu configuration file, and add a line such as the following, substituting the password hash obtained above:

password --md5

custom_item_776.description: GEN008520 - The system must employ a local firewall.
custom_item_776.info:
A local firewall protects the system from exposing unnecessary or undocumented network services to the local enclave.  If a system within the enclave is compromised, firewall protection on an individual system continues to protect it from attack.

NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_776.solution:
Enable the system's local firewall.
# svcadm enable network/ipfilter

custom_item_779.description: GEN008800 - The system package management tool must cryptographically verify the authenticity of software packages during installation.
custom_item_779.info: To prevent the installation of software from unauthorized sources, the system package management tool must use cryptographic algorithms to verify the packages are authentic.
custom_item_779.solution: Edit /var/sadm/install/admin/default and set the authentication setting to quit.

custom_item_780.description: GEN008820 - The system package management tool must not automatically obtain updates - /var/spool/cron/crontabs/*
custom_item_780.info: System package management tools can obtain a list of updates and patches from a package repository and make this information available to the SA for review and action. Using a package repository outside of the organization's control, presents a risk that malicious packages could be introduced.
custom_item_780.solution:
Disable any cron or at jobs running smpatch.

# crontab -e < user running smpatch >
# atrm < id of at job running smpatch >

custom_item_781.description: GEN008820 - The system package management tool must not automatically obtain updates - /var/spool/cron/atjobs/*
custom_item_781.info: System package management tools can obtain a list of updates and patches from a package repository and make this information available to the SA for review and action.
